pull.title: IMERC-307: Dropdowns pre selected
pull.body: Modified how Select work - Added placeholder prop - Modified styles - `defaultValue` removed - `value` should be handled by parent component (usually handled by `react-hook-form`'s `Controller` - removed `null` as a value type since we shouldn't have empty options now

comments.body: This setter function should probably be moved outside of this block. If a `programId` is never found/created, then this modal will never close.

`label` should never be null, otherwise we would show an empty option
```suggestion
  label: string;
```

`onChange` should be required, otherwise we would have a dropdown that does nothing when opened and clicked
```suggestion
  onChange: (value?: string | number) => void;
```
There's no relation between `selectedOption` and `mainElementClasses`, there should be a line break between both

Based on the suggestion above for `onChange`, this should also be changed
```suggestion
        onChange(val);
```

comments.body: We should probably put this `onClick={props.onExpandClick}` on the entire program card so that way when we click on program card it expands the children projects. It's a little odd that the card can be highlighted and yet when we click it nothing happens. If we do move the click handler, we'll have to change the `div` card wrapper to a `button` (or something equivalent). But I realize it may be tricky with the `<PopupActionsButton />`, but it's something to consider.

We can remove this whole `try/catch` since it won't actually work. I don't know what I was thinking here, but I think we can replace this with a `useEffect` and just watch for the `tagIndex` and update the current focused tag.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -28,73 +31,57 @@ export const ProjectCard: FC = ({ } = project; return ( -
-
-
comments.body: Archiving is a dangerous action, so this should be `danger: true`
We may want to add better error handling here. Perhaps we can do [something like this](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/discussions/12652) here?
There may be better error typing here too.
Same thing here. We might want to add a better typed error.
Same as comments above.

I've removed the highlighting and the pointer cursor for program cards. Eventually, we'll have program cards taking you to the actual program as we do with projects so I wouldn't want to modify it any further. Good callout!

`setFocusedTag` is also not an async function so I don't know why it's being awaited. Seems that a lot of things can be improved there but I don't think this PR is the best place for these changes, especially given the fact I didn't work on this component and haven't really used it at all.

Well, the actual error handling is ok, this was added by Johann a month ago approximately to show a session expired modal if the server returns an `access_token_expired` error.

If you're referring to the `any` typing, unfortunately TypeScript doesn't support typing errors yet, they can either be `any` or `unknown`. The only reason why I changed all of these to be an explicit `any` is because I upgraded TS to the latest version (4.4) which now by default sets all errors as `unknown` which broke the application.

comments.body: As mentioned by Chrissy, the exclamation mark shouldn't be removed

Seeing as we're defining `parameters` in the object being exported above, we should add this in there as well. Also, I tried different values "none", "padded", "centered" and "fullscreen" and saw no differences. Is this needed?
There should be spacing between the setter functions and the rest.
Chrissy mentioned that someone clicking on a required field and then clicking outside of it without filling it should show the error, so this should be probably set to `onBlur`
All of these fields are already marked as required by resolving our `formSchema` at the top so none of these rules should be necessary

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -19,18 +19,18 @@ export const projectEntitySchema = z.object({
   createdAt: z.string(),
   updatedAt: z.string(),
   deletedAt: z.date().nullable(),
-  name: z.string(),
+  name: z.string().nonempty(),
comments.body:
If you hover over this method it says that it's deprecated and `min(1)` should be used instead.
Also, this validation currently allows creation of projects with empty spaces `" "` as project name.

The suggested validation will: test against a trimmed version of the value `" " —> ""` (will throw an error as it's less than 1 char) and will also transform the value before being submitted `"       name —> "name"`.
```suggestion
  name: z.string().min(1).refine((value) => value.trim()).transform((value) => value.trim()),
```

pull.title: [IMERC-308]: Archive Warning Modal
pull.body:
## Changes

- add `"danger"` style to `Button`
- create `ArchiveProjectModal` to confirm user wants to archive project

### Context
[IMERC-308](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-308)

### Screenshots/videos
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/139370031-10f5785d-4e77-4f0c-bc98-5ce66871a66f.mov

comments.body:
As this is an async function it should be typed as `onSubmit: () => Promise<void>`

The editor should also help here as the expression on line 17 is highlighted with a message "'await' has no effect on the type of this expression", indicating it should either return a promise, or not be awaited at all

```suggestion
  onSubmit: () => Promise<void>;
```

Components should be typed with the FunctionComponent type or `FC` for short
```suggestion
export const ArchiveProjectModal: FC<ArchiveProjectModalProps> = ({ isOpen, onCancel, onSubmit }) => {
```

This function is only used on the `onClose` prop for the modal, so it would probably be better to name it either `handleClose` or `onClose`. Doing so will prevent confusion with the `onCancel` being used directly on the Cancel button.

Also, can we please have some line breaks between these functions? With how code minification and production bundles work today there's no need to have everything crammed

Seeing as we already have a Project type is better to reuse that rather than creating another super specific type
```suggestion
  const [projectToArchive, setProjectToArchive] = useState<ProjectEntity | null>(null);
```
Based on the comment above this can be removed entirely

The `deleteProject` function is already wrapped inside a try/catch block so this will never be executed. Also, if the API fails there's already a toast appearing on the top right saying that something went wrong so we would be showing two toasts at the same time. I'd say we can remove this part entirely and then look into improving error messages as part of the errors spike
This function should now receive the entire `project` object rather than separated properties

It was probably missed from my previous review but can we please add line breaks between functions? With how code minification and production bundles work today there's no need to have everything crammed
Forgot to mention this on my previous review but I'd suggest renaming this to something like `isArchiveProjectModalOpen` as we could eventually have more than just one modal.

Personal preference here but I think it's better to not destructure this. These values are only being used once so we are removing two words but adding an entire new line. I'd also say that `deleteProject(company.id, project.id)` is easier to read and understand as one can easily identify what that function expects. By just sending `id` this is more open to interpretation.

pull.title: [IMERC-208] Add city to point location
pull.body:
[IMERC-208](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-208)

**Issue:** 
CARTO API query is case insensitive, therefore,  even though I was aliasing `name10` as `urbanArea`, the value returned would be on the property `urbanarea` (without the uppercase A), thus, the method `getUrbanAreaAtPosition` would return an `undefined` value that triggers the fallback to county behavior.

**Fix:**
change alias from `urbanArea` to `urbanarea`

pull.title: [IMERC-187]: Fix Manual Modification Drag Error
pull.body:
## Changes

- modify `handleDragging` and `handleStopDragging` of `EditMode`

### Context

- [IMERC-187](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-187)

comments.body: Is `undefined` needed as a return type?
According to the types being used `featureIndex` is a number so it won't ever be `undefined`. Is there any valid scenario where this is not a number?

This entire block is exactly the same as the one above except for having `finishMovePosition` as `editType` instead of `movePosition`. To prevent code duplication this block should be defined as its own function and then called from within the two handlers.
These `drag` and `editHandle` functions are exactly what's in their source code, except for the check to see if the feature exists.
Yeah, I saw the duplication as well but wasn't sure how to DRY it up. Thanks!

I don't think this line is necessary. If `picks` is not defined then `getPickedEditHandles(picks)` will return an empty array and then because its length is 0 the function will return `null`.

I'd also say that writing the line below as `handles.length > 0` is better than just `handles.length`. Even though the outcome is the same the first option is easier to read and understand.
`picks` should be optional, otherwise we need to add the extra condition as commented above and the ternary will always default to the first expression as it will always be true

same comment as above
This event is triggered even if I click on the sidebar, therefore, the tooltip disappears even if no point was placed
This was a total oversight. Thanks for catching that!
State and setter function should follow the same naming structure, `setShowDrawMessage`
refs should never be used as dependencies as they don't trigger re-renders. because `modificationMode` is being read from inside the effect, it should be added instead

comments.body: What is `start` supposed to be? There's no correlation between the name and the `ReactNode` type so it's hard to understand. Also, we're only using this component in a single place which receives the `start` prop so should this be optional?
Following the comment above, is there a reason to have `start` as a prop? I feel it would be better to just have it as part of the `Details` component

As to avoid repeating ourselves here we can do something like

```
const MarkerComponent = size === 'sm' ? MarkerSmall : MarkerDefault;
return <MarkerComponent text={text} fillClass={fillClass} borderClass={borderClass} textClass={textClass} />
```
This condition should be below the other `(index === userDefinedPoints.length - 1)` otherwise if there's only one point it will be marked as `end` when it should be `start`
This condition should be below the other `(index === userDefinedPoints.length - 1)` otherwise if there's only one point it will be labeled 'E' instead of 'S'
This notation is totally fine but as we use `Array<T>` pretty much everywhere else it might be better to keep consistency across the board

Any reason in particular why these functions are created as actual `function` instead of arrows functions? If there isn't, I would again suggest for consistency reasons to convert them to arrow functions
Same comment as above about arrow functions and array type notation
This is an async function so we should `await` it
I get an ESLint error when awaiting this function that states that we shouldnt await when returning a `Promise` in an async function since it will be awaited by the caller if needed

pull.title: IMERC-173: business size validation
pull.body:
Update business size validation rules

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30033816/136389621-8e54ffd4-5383-4521-8f42-1c3468e2abea.mov

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -15,7 +15,12 @@ export const companyProperties = z.object({
     .min(1)
     .refine((v) => v.trim())
     .transform((v) => v.trim()),
-  size: z.number().positive(),
+  size: z
+    .string()
+    .refine((val) => !!val && val.trim().length > 0, 'This field is required')
+    .refine((val) => !Number.isNaN(Number(val)), 'Value must be a number')
+    .transform(Number)
+    .refine((val) => val > 0, 'Value must be positive'),
comments.body:
- By using `.min(1)` we're using the same validation as in other fields, which will return the same error message.
- By moving `.transform(Number)` one line above, we remove the need to cast the value as a number on line 21.
- By checking if value is a number and bigger than 0, we're merging two validations into a single one, which will also take into consideration strings and whitespaces (`Number(' ')` returns 0)
```suggestion
  size: z
    .string()
    .min(1)
    .transform(Number)
    .refine((value) => !Number.isNaN(value) && value !== 0, 'Value must be a positive number'),
```

pull.title: IMERC-174: Autoformat EIN
pull.body:
[IMERC-174](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-174)

- Autoformat EIN places hyphen after 2nd character
- Validate that EIN has 10 characters
- Validate that all characters are numeric

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30033816/136388201-b3fdf836-b2ad-4bae-8d92-68903c46b411.mov

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,9 +18,8 @@ export const companyProperties = z.object({
   size: z.number().positive(),
   ein: z
     .string()
-    .min(1)
-    .refine((v) => v.trim())
-    .transform((v) => v.trim()),
+    .length(10)
comments.body:
Current error shows "Should be at least 10 characters" if less than 10 and "Should be at most 10 characters long" if more than 10 which doesn't really make sense. By adding our own custom message we're giving a better explanation on what's needed.
```suggestion
    .length(10, 'EIN should be 10 characters long')
```

We really only want to format the value when it's length is equal to two, rather than more than two. It probably won't make any difference in performance but it's a free win.
```suggestion
  const formatEIN = (value: string) => value.length === 2 ? value.replace(/(.{2})-?(.*)/, '$1-$2') : value;
```
This would not format pasted input longer than 2 characters.
That's absolutely true, I missed that completely.

pull.title: bugfix/[IMERC-158]: Save Modification Hangs
pull.body:
### Context
[IMERC-158](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-158)

### Changes

- Use polygon boundaries instead of point indices to tell whether a modification is overlapping a point/other mod
- If a modification disconnects a lateral, update the state to reflect that
- Remove formatting on optimized points (this was contributing to the app crashing)

comments.body:
We should maintain consistency with the rest of the file
```suggestion
  const featureLineString = [...geoJson.features[featureIndex].geometry.coordinates] as Array<Position>;
```
Brackets are always recommended if the condition is multiline as it's less confusing.
Should this be `isInvalidPolygon`? I'm not sure if this is trying to convey an invalid polygon or if something is inside a valid polygon.
Why not use a `for` loop instead?
`j` is only used on line 244, it would be simpler to just use `i + 1` instead of declaring a new variable
This should probably be a `for` loop as well
Variables declarations should always be on top of the condition, so this should be moved to line 255
This can be simplified by just having `i +=1` and removing `j` entirely. Doing `i = j` is confusing. Even better is just using a `for` loop as mentioned above

This entire thing is super confusing to read and I feel like if we had better naming then things could get easier. For instance `isOverlapping` is not clear what it means. What is overlapping what?

I understand there's a distinction between one overlapping something, or one being overlapped by something but it's not clear unless one takes time to read the whole thing. Line 268 you check if current overlaps next or if current overlaps prev, but on line 269 you do it the other way around, you first check for prev and then check for next. Line 268 is also "positive" while line 269 is "negative". These things separated from each other might not mean much, but when everything is put together it ends up being confusing.

The if condition on line 271 is confusing too, if `isOverlapping` is true, we're pushing `current` to a `withoutOverlaps` array. Does that mean that if it's overlapping, then it won't be overlapped? If that's true, then why is it needed to create variables for both `isOverlapping` and `isNotOverlapped`?

+  featureCollection: GeoJSON,

+) => {

```suggestion
export const updateLineStringPointToNearestOnRoute = (

```

Renaming this method would make it easier to understand. 

However, I would still expect it to only have 3 parameters `lineString`, `pointIndex` and `route`, it would be awesome if thats possible, if not, only renaming it will help.

same as above

pull.body:
## Changes:
- Shows sign in and sign up button if user isn't logged in
- Shows sign out button if user is logged in

pull.title: [Snyk] Upgrade react-redux from 7.2.4 to 7.2.5
pull.body:
Snyk has created this PR to upgrade react-redux from 7.2.4 to 7.2.5.

:sparkles: Snyk has automatically assigned this pull request, [set who gets assigned](https://app.snyk.io/org/imercatus/project/95fba3d2-9a74-46ba-a36d-c4f2cdc496fa/settings/integration?utm_source=github&utm_medium=referral&page=upgrade-pr/settings/integration). :information_source: Keep your dependencies up-to-date. This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
- The recommended version is **1 version** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **a month ago**, on 2021-09-04.
Release notes
Package name: react-redux
  • 7.2.5 - 2021-09-04

    This release shrinks the size of our internal Subscription class, and updates useSelector to avoid an unnecessary selector call on mount.

    Changes

    Subscription Size Refactor

    Our internal Subscription implementation has been written as a class ever since it was added in v5. By rewriting it as a closure factory, we were able to shave a few bytes off the final bundle size.

    useSelector Mount Optimization

    A user noticed that useSelector had never been given an early "bail out if the root state is the same" check to match how connect works. This resulted in a usually-unnecessary second call to the provided selector on mount. We've added that check.

    Entry Point Consolidation

    We've consolidated the list of exported public APIs into a single file, and both the index.js and alternate-renderers.js entry points now re-export everything from that file. No meaningful change here, just shuffling lines of code around for consistency.

    Other Updates

    React-Redux v8 and React 18 Development

    With the announcement of React 18, we've been working with the React team to plan our migration path to keep React-Redux fully compatible with React's upcoming features.

    We've already migrated the React-Redux main development branch to TypeScript, and are prototyping compatibility implementation updates. We'd appreciate any assistance from the community in testing out these changes so that we can ensure React-Redux works great for everyone when React 18 is ready!

    Internal Tooling Updates

    Our master branch now uses Yarn v2 for package management, is built with TypeScript, and we've made CI updates to test against multiple TS versions.

    The 7.x branch has also been updated to use Yarn v2 for consistency.

    These only affect contributors to the React-Redux package itself.

    Changelog

    • Port entry point consolidation from 8.x branch (#1811 - @ markerikson)
    • Update v7 branch to use Yarn v2 and improve CI process (#1810 - @ markerikson)
    • Reduce unnecessary calls to useSelector selector (#1803 - @ sufian-slack )
    • Port Subscription closure implementation from 8.x to 7.x (#1809 - @ mbelsky)

    v7.2.4...v7.2.5

  • 7.2.4 - 2021-04-24

    This release drops our dependency on the core redux package by inlining bindActionCreators, and tweaks useSelector to ensure that selectors aren't run an extra time while re-rendering.

    Changelog

    Redux Dependency Removal

    React-Redux has always imported the bindActionCreators utility from the core redux package for use in connect. However, that meant that we had to have a peer dependency on redux, and this was the only reason we actually required that redux be installed. This became more annoying with the arrival of Redux Toolkit, which has its own dependency on redux internally, and thus users typically saw peer dependency warnings saying that "redux isn't listed as a dependency in your app".

    Code reuse across separate packages is a great thing, but sometimes the right thing to do is duplicate code. So, we've inlined bindActionCreators directly into React-Redux, and we've completely dropped the dependency on Redux. This means that React-Redux will no longer produce a peerDep warning when used with Redux Toolkit, and <Provider> and connect really only need a Redux-store-compatible value to work right.

    useSelector Fixes

    Users reported that useSelector was re-running selector functions again unnecessarily while rendering after a dispatch. We've tweaked the logic to ensure that doesn't happen.

    useSelector also now has checks in development to ensure that selector and equalityFn are functions.

    Changes

    • Remove wrapActionCreators (#1709 - @ xty)
    • Verify that selector and equalityF of useSelector are functions (#1706 - @ gshilin)
    • Import bindActionCreators from redux (#1705 - @ timdorr)
    • Don't re-run the selector after update (#1701 - @ timdorr)

    v7.2.3...v7.2.4

pull.title: [Snyk] Upgrade react-router-dom from 5.2.1 to 5.3.0
pull.body:
Snyk has created this PR to upgrade react-router-dom from 5.2.1 to 5.3.0.

![merge advice](https://app.snyk.io/badges/merge-advice/?package_manager=npm&package_name=react-router-dom&from_version=5.2.1&to_version=5.3.0&pr_id=b918ef97-e6f6-4c6e-8707-a5a2ce6c1119&visibility=true&has_feature_flag=false) :sparkles: Snyk has automatically assigned this pull request, [set who gets assigned](https://app.snyk.io/org/imercatus/project/95fba3d2-9a74-46ba-a36d-c4f2cdc496fa/settings/integration?utm_source=github&utm_medium=referral&page=upgrade-pr/settings/integration). :information_source: Keep your dependencies up-to-date. This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
- The recommended version is **1 version** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **a month ago**, on 2021-09-03.
Release notes
Package name: react-router-dom
  • 5.3.0 - 2021-09-03

    This release of react-router-dom adds support for passing a function to either the className or style props to conditionally apply values based on the link's active state.

    This provides similar functionality as the existing activeClassName and activeStyle props, but is a bit more powerful. For example, you can now easily apply styles exclusively to an inactive NavLink as well. This offers a nicer experience for folks who use utility class-based CSS tools such as Tailwind.

    function Comp() {
  return (
    <NavLink
      to="/"
      className={isActive =>
        `px-3 py-2 ${isActive ? 'text-gray-200' : 'text-gray-800'}`
      }
    >
      Home
    </NavLink>
  );
}

    Note that as of v6.0.0-beta.3, the activeClassName and activeStyle props are removed completely. Adding support for functional className and style props to both v5 and v6 will give v5 users an easier upgrade path.

    Thanks to @ tim-phillips for raising the issue that inspired the change! 🥳

  • 5.2.1 - 2021-08-27

    This release fixes a bug with <Link> so that, when the to location is the same as the current, the history state entry is replaced instead of pushed to the stack. See #5362 for details. 🥳

    Thanks to @ guidobouman for the PR and for everyone else who weighed in for the fix!

pull.title: [IMERC-124] Spread Optimizations
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Spreads now start and end on an optimized point, rather than anywhere on the optimized line
- Replaces turf's lineSlice with a more performant custom getLineSlice function
- Re-uses route and lateral markers and changes their style on tab change instead of destroying/creating every time

## Context:
[IMERC-124](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-124)

## Videos (OLD vs NEW):

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8879212/135506435-94c56388-da62-4bdf-b933-41fb5735f56a.mov

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8879212/135506733-8f2a39c7-8071-4d28-876c-6c8482f096f4.mov

comments.body: what is the total size of this array usually?
This works great when the marker is always moved along the optimized line, but crashes when it's moved outside of it. I think #368 should fix this. So maybe we should merge that one before this one?
Good catch. #368 has already been merged so we should be good.

Not that big. On a 1000 mile long route we would have 10 spread labels, 9 spread markers and X default markers based on the amount of user defined points the route has, but usually not that many. Having laterals would also create additional markers but would still be a relatively low amount of items.

pull.title: IMERC-37: Snap to spread end marker to optimized line
pull.body:
[IMERC-37](https://imercata.atlassian.net/secure/RapidBoard.jsparapidView=1&projectKey=IMERC&modal=detail&selectedIssue=IMERC-37)

- Use `GeoJsonLayer` instead of `MapboxMarker` to render spread ends
- Snapping. behavior is handled by `onSpreadMarkerDrag`

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@
+<svg width="43" height="45" viewBox="0 0 43 45" fill="none"
+    xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
+    <g opacity="0.7" filter="url(#filter0_d)">
comments.body: Maybe we can download higher width/height versions of these icons, and then inside of `getIcon` we can determine the width to display it. That might help with the quality of the image when it's rendered on the map. I remember doing something similar when I was experimenting with `IconLayer` from `deck.gl`.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@
+<svg width="43" height="45" viewBox="0 0 43 45" fill="none"
+    xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
+    <g opacity="0.7" filter="url(#filter0_d)">
comments.body: Fixed icon quality on new commit, followed your advice 👍

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -402,6 +401,19 @@ export const ProjectMap: FC<ProjectMapProps> = ({
         ...spreadsData
           .reverse()
           .map(({ name, line, isActive }) => createSpreadPathLayer(name, line, isActive)),
+        ...spreadsData
+          .filter((item) => !item.isLast)
+          .map(({ routeIndex, spreadIndex, line, isActive }) =>
+            createSpreadEndMarker(
+              routeIndex,
+              spreadIndex,
+              line,
+              isActive,
+              viewport.bearing,
+              onSpreadMarkerDrag,
+              onSpreadMarkerDragEnd,
+            ),
+          ),
comments.body:
I understand that markers are now layers and why they're being created here now, but it's confusing having a `createSpreadEndMarker` function inside `createPathLayers` when we have a `createMarkers` function below.

Should we change the name of `createSpreadEndMarker` to better represent what it returns? Also, does it make sense for this to be called `EndMarker`? These markers change two spreads at a time so they're technically positioned at the end of one, but at the start of the other.

I believe there are some issues with the `mode` property, but if that's causing the issue it's better to just `// @ts-ignore` that rather than typing the entire instance as `any` as we're losing lots of valuable information.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@
+<svg width="180" height="180" viewBox="0 0 43 45" transform="rotate(139)" fill="none"
comments.body:
The svgs are of different size and is noticeable while changing the active spread. We can also optimize them using a tool like SVGOMG (https://jakearchibald.github.io/svgomg/) to reduce their file size.

Also, this one seems to have a `rotate(139)` while the other has `rotate(91)`, is there a specific reason for that? Might be better to have both of them to be as similar as possible.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@
+<svg width="180" height="180" viewBox="0 0 43 45" transform="rotate(139)" fill="none"
comments.body: I optimized the icon as suggested, also both icons are almost equal, only difference is the background color

pull.title: resolve qa -> staging merge conflicts
pull.body:
in order to resolve merge conflicts between `qa` and `staging`, first we need to bring the tip of qa to match the tip of staging - this comes with no code changes and only affects the commit history
```
> git merge staging --strategy ours
```

pull.title: bugifx/[IMERC-125]: Close Spread Menu When Clicking Outside
pull.body:
## Changes

- Create `useClickOutside` hook; used to determine if an element has been clicked outside of given reference element

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/134965635-9fdbd60c-7ec3-48d4-a215-7139631ed67e.mov

comments.body: `isClickedOutSide` can sometimes be null, hence the OR operator.

Nitpicking here, but it's recommended to always type refs as that changes their internal behaviour.

For example: declaring this as `const wrapperRef = useRef(null);` will give `wrapperRef` a type of `MutableRefObject<null>`

If we were to type the ref, `const wrapperRef = useRef<HTMLElement>(null);` then its type will be `RefObject<HTMLElement>`

As you can see, it won't be mutable anymore, meaning that doing something like `wrapperRef.current = "hello"` will throw an error.

Won't really change that much for this case, but it's good to be as strict as possible to avoid any possible errors.

No need to type `isClickedOutSide` as that's already defined inside the hook.

Nitpicking again but it's probably better to define the param as `_isClickedOutside` rather than `isClickedOutSide`
`ref` will always exist, no need to add `?`
We can be more consistent renaming naming this variable to `isClickedOutside`

Mutation is done on purpose to handle projectName between project and mainRoute specs

Release notes
Package name: react-router-dom
  • 5.2.1 - 2021-08-27

    This release fixes a bug with <Link> so that, when the to location is the same as the current, the history state entry is replaced instead of pushed to the stack. See #5362 for details. 🥳

    Thanks to @ guidobouman for the PR and for everyone else who weighed in for the fix!

  • 5.2.0 - 2020-05-11

    This release includes a notable performance boost by separating the "Router" context from the "History" context internally. We also allow every element type for Link's component prop and support a sensitive prop on NavLink for control over case sensitive matching.

    Enjoy!

    Changes

    • Add sensitive prop on NavLink (#7251 by @ caseywebdev)
    • Fix Link component prop type check (#7276 by @ ypyakymiv)
    • Update mini-create-react-context (#7288 by @ patricksmms)
    • Separate history to its own context (#7103 by @ illuminist)

pull.title: [IMERC-12]: Visual Map Settings GIS Layers
pull.body:
## Acceptance Criteria
- [x] Users can select many layers across many categories
- [x] Selected layers should persist until the user de-selects them for the given project (even after user reloads page)
- [x] Clicking "Apply" should apply the desired layers to the Map UI

## Context
[IMERC-12](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-12)

## Note
Must run [IMERC-25 PR](https://github.com/iMercatus/imercata-backend/pull/145) in BE to test this pull request.

comments.body: We shouldn't do this. Chromatic is a tool that's supposed to help us, not limit us. If tests/stories are failing due to something in our code we should then try to figure out what's not working instead of circumventing the issue. It seems there are several ways of mocking the router by using decorators.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -30,6 +30,7 @@
   "dependencies": {
     "@auth0/nextjs-auth0": "^1.5.0",
     "@danmarshall/deckgl-typings": "^4.9.3",
+    "@deck.gl/carto": "^8.5.9",
comments.body:
We shouldn't install deck.gl submodules (except extensions) as they are already bundled in the `deck.gl` package. 

Importing something from `@deck.gl/carto` without having the actual package installed will probably make ESLint complain about extraneous dependencies but I believe for this case it's not an issue as this is how DeckGL recommends using their library. If we only import this in a single place we can probably just disable linter for that line, otherwise it'd be good to set the rule as a warning in the eslint config file
Was this a requirement? I believe we discussed this previously and said it would behave kind of like Google Maps where all modifications to the view/layers only last during the session

No change needed but IMO, early returns are great to avoid having entire functions nested within an if but I'm not a big fan of using it this way.

For me, for cases like this it makes sense if (response) { do this }, rather than the opposite.
Super minor but this should be `@/entities'
Oops! Yeah, I think the autocomplete did that. My bad!

As I understand it, yes. The map settings need to persist between reloads and different projects. 

>  Selected layers should persist until the user de-selects them for the given project (even after user reloads page)

pull.title: IMERC-17 Update BE on every undo/redo
pull.body:
[IMERC-17](https://imercata.atlassian.net/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=1&projectKey=IMERC&modal=detail&selectedIssue=IMERC-17)

- [x] ~~Disable undo/redo buttons while the route is being saved to the backend~~ (Bad UX)
- [x] Debounce `updateRoute` API call
- [x] Call debounced method on undo/redo
- [ ] ~Display loading icon~ Will be included on a following ticket

comments.body: does this work fine now with tree-shaking? isn't the recommendation to use `import debounce from 'lodash/debounce'`?
I'm not sure, I'll double check analyzing the generated bundle.
Shouldn't we just use the debounced version on undo/redo?

IMO this method should be used on most scenarios since it helps us avoid sync issues without any significant tradeoff. It would help in other (not so common) scenarios such as the user moving markers rapidly
Fixed on new commit
If we're only using this variable once, we can delete this and insert the time delay directly into the debounce function.

These functions share some similar logic. We can probably make a single function that determines the data that should be returned for a `redo` and an `undo`. 

Moreover, we need to add in the soft delete endpoints.
This is nitpicky, and I'm not sure of the value here, but I noticed lines `213`, `217`, and `221` are essentially the same function, so we can probably make one `find` function.

pull.title: IMERC-38: Fix route deoptimizes when changing point name
pull.body:
[IMERC-38](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-38)

- Decouple update point event into "update point name" and "update point coordinates" (for both laterals and main route)
- Both events are saved to the backend but only "update point coordinates" deoptimizes the route

    z.preprocess

    This lets you transform input data before it is parsed by your schema. This is useful for several use cases, notably type coercion. Usage:

    const coercedString = z.preprocess(
  val => String(val),
  z.string()
)
mySchema.parse(12); // => "12"
mySchema.parse(true); // => "true"

    CUID validation

    Courtesy of @ alii

    const cuid = z.string().cuid()
cuid.parse("ckopqwooh000001la8mbi2im9");

    Improved .deepPartial()

    The .deepPartial() method on object schemas now recursively traverses through ZodArray, ZodTuple, ZodOptional, and ZodNullable elements. Previously, this method only worked in hierarchies of simple object schemas.

    const mySchema = z.object({
  name: z.string(),
  array: z.array(z.object({ asdf: z.string() })),
  tuple: z.tuple([
    z.object({ value: z.string() })
  ]),
}) 

const partialed = mySchema.deepPartial();
type partialed = z.infer<typeof partialed>;
/*
  {
    name?: string | undefined;
    array?: {
        asdf?: string | undefined;
    }[] | undefined;
    tuple?: [{value?: string}] | undefined;
  }
*/
  • 3.7.3 - 2021-08-19

    Improve Zod stack traces

  • 3.7.2 - 2021-08-13
  • 3.7.1 - 2021-08-01

pull.body:
Snyk has created this PR to upgrade react-hook-form from 7.12.2 to 7.13.0.

![merge advice](https://app.snyk.io/badges/merge-advice/?package_manager=npm&package_name=react-hook-form&from_version=7.12.2&to_version=7.13.0&pr_id=08dc091a-adae-4f2e-a8dc-17a8738791e2&visibility=true&has_feature_flag=false) :sparkles: Snyk has automatically assigned this pull request, [set who gets assigned](https://app.snyk.io/org/imercatus/project/95fba3d2-9a74-46ba-a36d-c4f2cdc496fa/settings/integration?utm_source=github&utm_medium=upgrade-pr/settings/integration). :information_source: Keep your dependencies up-to-date. This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
- The recommended version is **7 versions** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **24 days ago**, on 2021-08-22.
Release notes
Package name: react-hook-form
  • 7.13.0 - 2021-08-22

    🏎 Performance enhancement at scale

    React hook from is getting a general performance upgrade and enhancement. The following API will get big performance improvement at scale, which means it may not improve on small or medium-size applications, but rather large and complex applications with subscriptions.

    • useWatch
    • useFieldArray
    • watch
    • getValues

    Result Env: dev build + throttle 4x CPU + Chrome + MAC M1

    Version Flat (1000) Nested (1000) Deeply Nested (1000 * 2 * 2000) Flat (1000) Mount
    7.13.0-next.0 18ms 20ms 200ms 470ms (no change)
    7.11.1 40ms 43ms 2000ms 470ms

    📦 Package size-reduction

    • 5% package size reduction with compress and gzip

    Total Size: 30.3 kB

    Filename Size Change
    dist/index.cjs.js 8.39 kB -445 B (5%) ✅
    dist/index.esm.js 13.4 kB -656 B (4%)
    dist/index.umd.js 8.52 kB -420 B (4%)

    🔫 Trigger

    • Trigger will enable object name trigger and field array name trigger
    useFieldArray({ name: 'test' })

trigger('name') // will trigger the whole field array to validate

    📑 register

    • added a disabled prop as an option to toggle input disable attribute
    • register will be able to seek input DOM reference through the ref callback
    register('test', { disabled: true }) // will set value to undeinfed and pass disabled down to the input attribute

<div {...register('test')}>
  <input name="test" /> // this input will be registered
</div>

    👀 useWatch

    • added disabled prop to toggle the state subscription.
    useWatch({ disabled: true }) // you toggle the subscription

    ⌨️ useFormState

    • added disabled prop to toggle the state subscription.
    useFormState({ disabled: true }) // you toggle the subscription

    ⛳️ setValue

    • allow set value for non-registered inputs include nested object and array field.
    <input {...register('test.0.firstName')} />

setValue('test', [{ firstName: 'bill' }, {firstName: 'kotaro}, {firstName: 'joris'}]) // this will works

    Resolved issues:

    ⏱️ close #6296 abort validation early when disable prop is detected (#6300)
    🎹 fix #6265 objects may have error messages (#6275)
    🔄 fix #6277 track async validate to trigger state update (#6284)
    🐞 fix #6272 only flush field array when subscription name match (#6281)
    💪🏻 simplify fillEmptyArray and combine focus name (#6237)
    🌵 remove redundant code for useFieldArray (#6236)
    🐞 patch remove, update api with key id persist (#6235)
    🐞 close #6233 for persist field array id (#6234)
    🍄 enable detect fields unmount at useWatch level (#6226)
    💨 improve useFieldArray perf (#6215)
    🍨 close #6193 to remove shallow merge with defaultValue with watch (#6201)
    🐞 fix #6186 delayError with set error after delay (#6188)
    ☄️ enhance unregister unmount inputs by combining its logic (#6185)
    🖨️ include reset clone value for array/object/date (#6183)
    👨🏻‍🔧 fix rendering order with useFieldArray (#6182)
    🎭 skip the shallow clone with useForm return (#6154)
    ⌨️ fix: WatchObserver info name type (#6171)

  • 7.13.0-next.5 - 2021-08-15

    🐞 patch remove, update API with key id persist (#6235)

  • 7.13.0-next.4 - 2021-08-15

    🐞 close #6233 for persist field array id (#6234)
    🍄 enable detect fields unmount at useWatch level (#6226)

pull.title: Update deck.gl, nebula.gl and react-map-gl to latest versions
[IMERC-34] Route Planner improvements
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Moves all segment related functionality to helper functions as done with spreads
- Renames Redux's state properties and reducers to better indicate their purpose
- Change to look for laterals using id instead of index to prevent desync issues
- Misc improvements and renaming

## Context:
IMERC-34

comments.body: This seems to redraw the new modified line but it isn't accounting for disconnected laterals. If you redraw the line, and the main line isn't attached to the lateral anymore, there is no error state indicating a disconnected lateral. You'll have to check if each lateral is connected (ie `isConnected: checkIfLateralIsConnectedToRoute(lateral, updatedRoute)`) and update the route's lateral accordingly.

pull.body:
# Changes:
- Change base map layer
- Change overlays (currently non-functional)

## Context:
[IMERC-11](https://imercata.atlassian.net/browse/IMERC-11)

## Screenshots/videos:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/133731350-f5c14b6c-0e63-4e09-9bff-7f037418020a.mov

comments.body: can we rename this to `weight`? to be compliant with tailwind naming https://tailwindcss.com/docs/font-weight

I know you didn't create this file but it'd be great to refactor stuff as we go back to it, such as:
- Destructuring props inside params (no need to initialize `disabled` or `dataTestId` as they are falsy anyways)
- Add line breaks, no need to have everything crammed
- `classes` just adds a disabled cursor state but that can be used directly in `base` by setting `disabled:cursor-not-allowed`
- As `classes` is not needed anymore, `base` should be renamed to a more appropriate name or even removed in favour of inline classes

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,62 @@
+/* eslint-disable @next/next/no-img-element */
comments.body: We dont need to disable eslint since it is only a warning, however we can try to use Next's Image component here
The difference between layers and overlays is not clear to me. Can we have just one `layers` array with a `selected` property for each item?
This should probably be named `MapSettingsLayer`
Why is this needed?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,62 @@
+/* eslint-disable @next/next/no-img-element */
comments.body: Not necessarily needed but Next now provides a better [Image component](https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/image) that replaces `img`. Did you try using it?

we should rename this to onToggleOverlays since it is an event handler. Also, we can look into splitting this event into `onToggleCategory` and `onToggleOverlay` so that most of the work (finding which overlays are part of that category) is done on the parent component

Would it make things easier it this data is an array of categories instead of an array of layers?

```
[
  {
    "name": "Map Details",
    "layers": [
      {
        "id": 10,
        "labelname": "Cell Towers",
        "sourceurl": "Cellular_Towers",
        "sql": "N",
        "resourceuri": "Cellular_Towers",
        "minzoom": 0,
        "maxzoom": 15,
        "servicetype": "",
        "query": "",
        "geom": null
      },
      {
        "id": 11,
        "labelname": "Cell Tower 2s",
        "sourceurl": "Cellular_Towers",
        "sql": "N",
        "resourceuri": "Cellular_Towers",
        "minzoom": 0,
        "maxzoom": 15,
        "servicetype": "",
        "query": "",
        "geom": null
      }
    ]
  }
...  
]
```
This is not needed. As the comment above explains, the only reason why we have these local "copies" is to avoid updating Redux's store multiple times while dragging markers.
Map settings are only used for the ProjectMap so everything related to it should live in there.
This won't be necessary with the changes above.
As mentioned above, all of these properties should live within the ProjectMap, there's no need to declare everything in here just to pass it down as props.

I'd say using Redux is not needed at all.
- We don't need to access these values from somewhere else
- We don't need to undo/redo any of these actions

One of its benefits is to avoid prop drilling, but you're doing that anyways as you're passing down the local "copies" of these values. We can have local state inside ProjectMap and pass that down to the settings modal.
`MapSettings` seems to be the "bigger" thing here. IMO it makes more sense to have `MapSettings` be the name of the folder rather than `MapSettingsModal`
Why did you change this? `isOptimizing` is now required.

This will probably change but this shouldn't be needed, nor the state on line 128. Component should re-render when its `mapStyle` prop changes and that should update the `mapStyle` prop being passed down to the `StaticMap` component
It's better to let TypeScript infer the type of the object rather than typing it yourself in this way as you lose autocompletion.

This entire component should not live inside here. It's fairly common to declare small components with others in the same file but this one has its own type, state and functions.

Also, there's a high chance that we'll need to re use this kind of component somewhere else so it's probably better to create this as a standalone reusable component.
Why not use `mapOverlay` and `mapHighlights` from props directly?

I see that you do this often, declaring an index signature. IMO this is most of the time considered bad practice for the following reasons:
- You're declaring an object `overlays`, by its name one can infer you're talking about an array that contains multiple `overlay`, not an object containing numbers.
- This is how the object looks like `overlays: {10: 10, 11: 11, 12: 12, 13: 13, 14: 14}` which makes no sense at all.
- Due to this, you then need to do stuff like this `Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call(overlays, overlayId);` which is not intuitive at all.

If you were to have this as an `Array<MapOverlay>` it could look something like this: `overlays = [{ id: 10, isChecked: true }, { id: 11, isChecked: false }, { id: 37, isChecked: false }]`. The `isChecked` function would then receive an `overlayId`, look for that in the array and check its `isChecked` property. Feels way more natural and intuitive.
As we're only using this constant 1 place it might be better to have it inline, removing the need for an explicit return.
This is confusing, what's the difference between Overlay and Layer? `currentCategoryOverlays` is an `Array<MapSettingLayer>` which doesn't make much sense
We shouldn't use `onClick` on divs unless needed for some reason. This should be a `button` element.
This is redundant. Effect will run on the `useEffect` below.
This should be on a separate utils file.

All of these functions can be removed by having a better data structure. As mentioned on a comment in `MapSettings`, if `overlays` was an array then all of these values can be inferred from it.

`onToggleAllByCategory` would iterate the array and set `isChecked` to true on all items.
`onToggleOverlay` would iterate the array and set `isChecked` to true on the overlay with `overlayId`.
`areAllChecked` would iterate the array and return true if `.every` is checked.
I'm not entirely sure what's happening here or what's the intent. I'm just marking this as I expect these to be changed as other stuff changes.
At some point the checkbox wasn't clickable (which is really weird). But I removed it and it works now. So I'm confused. 🤷‍♂️
Oh sorry! I didn't notice the `?` was removed in the diff. I'll make it required.
Essentially, I need a copy of the "old" state and the "new" state in order to determine when to enable the `Update` button.

At the moment, the data that is anticipated to be returned from the API looks like a list of layers (or overlay info, I'm not sure exactly what they're called) : 
```
[{
    id: 1,
    labelname: 'Cell Towers',
    category: 'map details',
    subcategory: null,
    sourceurl: 'Cellular_Towers',
    sql: 'N',
    resourceuri: 'Cellular_Towers',
    minzoom: 0,
    maxzoom: 15,
    servicetype: '',
    query: '',
    geom: null,
  },
  {
    id: 2,
    labelname: 'US Port Facilities',
    category: 'layers',
    subcategory: 'geographic',
    sourceurl: 'major_us_port_facilities',
    sql: 'N',
    resourceuri: 'major_us_port_facilities',
    minzoom: 0,
    maxzoom: 15,
    servicetype: '',
    query: '',
    geom: null,
  },]
```

These are not grouped by category. They are all just sort of lumped in together. But the UI shows that each overlay(?) should be grouped by category. This function is supposed to do that. 

**Note: I've named the second entry of the example data `'layers'`, but the list that Jordan provided only shows every category as being `'map details'`**
Yes, it would be easier because a lot of the work I'm doing is formatting the incoming data into groupings by category. If this can be done on the BE, then it makes everything easier.

This is definitely better than the previous iteration but there are still some issues:
- We're limiting ourselves to only 2 tabs
- There's hardcoded content that remove any reusability (eg: `text={currentTab === tab2 ? 'Layers' : 'Map Details'}`)
- `onClick` should probably be required as the purpose of this component is to switch between tabs so we need a function that determines how and when we switch
This seems to be referred as `mapStyle` on several places, should we rename `baseMap` —> `mapStyle`?

Shouldn't these be called `layers` rather than `overlays`? I think that's the term we usually use to refer to these. Also, it's kind of confusing that the `MapOverlay` component receives `mapOverlays` as they mean two completely different things

I'm not sure I understand this:
- What's the difference between `Overlay` and `MapSettingsOverlay`?
- Why does each overlay contain an `overlayCollection`?
- Why is the `& { isChecked: boolean }` extension needed?
- Why is this type being created inside the Modal?
Not sure the `local` prefix works here, maybe something like `currentBaseMapStyle` or `selectedBaseMapStyle`

This entire function seems to be super complex for just toggling the selected overlay/layer.

Receiving `type: 'check' | 'uncheck'` is not really needed as we have that information as part of the overlay object, we should just set the opposite of its current value.

We also have like 5 different iterations, even nested iterations. The way I imagine this function it receives an `overlayId`, looks for it and either checks or unchecks it, not sure why anything else is needed.

If we need to differentiate between category and overlay to know if all or just one should be checked we can either handle that on a separate function OR probably better, update the overlay type to have either a category or parent property.
I'm not sure it makes sense to store `isChecked`. We don't really care if the category is selected or not, but its layers.
`isChecked` shouldn't be part of the key as that will change. Doing that removes the whole purpose of using a `key` which is giving React the possibility of identifying items as to not re-render them
We shouldn't use `any`
I missed that hardcoded portion. Good eye!

I created this type instead of using an object with an index signature because you commented yesterday that an object with an index signature is too confusing, so I created this type to be more explicit in what the data represents.

I'm creating it in the Modal because I'm exporting the Modal, and it'd be easier to export it from the component that's being exported, rather trying to reexport it from the Modal (ie `export { Overlays } from ./MapSettings`;
I first need to group the incoming data by category and that's easiest by storing the collections of overlays in an object.
I did this to try to make things easier to read because, again, an object with a category pointing to an array of layers (overlays) was confusing.

This is not doing anything:
- Spreading an array previous to mapping is not needed as `.map` always returns a new array
- You're just returning each layer again, but spreaded in a new object
Nothing wrong here, but we should be consistent. You're not destructuring on line 50/51 but you're here.
No need to type the parameter
No need to type the parameter

Why are we bundling all modals in a single component? It's easier and more clean to just have them in `MapOverlay` as they were. `Modals` is receiving 5 props, only 1 of them is used for the `RoutePlannerCustomLayersUpload` component. Same thing with the `projectId`, we're getting it here although it's only used for one of them.

Also, not sure if it happened here but the styling for the `RoutePlannerCustomLayersUpload` component is off, it's not aligned correctly to the right.
@msallent I'm bundling the modals because Chromatic was failing its build due to the use of `useParams`.

@msallent The spread inside of map is needed in order to get a deep clone. If not, it'll just be a shallow clone, which when updating a local copy of the map settings will inadvertently update the parent copy because they share the same instance. 

However, I do agree that the first spread (`[...layerToUpdate.layers]`) is not needed.

comments.body: This can probably be its own component. It's not really clear what's happening here.
Agreed, will extract it as a new component
These numbers seem to a be a little bit random. Should we store them in a const to better represent what they mean? We can have them inside this same file.
We can apply the same logic in here. If they are spread markers then show this, otherwise show the default markers.

This map is just returning the same array, but flattened. If that's the only intention then we should either just call `.flat()` or we should replace the `map` above with `flatMap`.

Also, there are a lot going on here. Should we maybe store all this different maps as variables and then use them here?

Nothing wrong with this but I'm not a fan of inline SVGs in components. Seeing as we have an `svgs` folder, do you think it would be better to create them in there and then just reference them in here?
Not really an issue but spreading is not necessary here.
refactored on new commit
Just moved `SpreadMarker` to a new file, Im not using this switch statement now

yeah I wanted to place them on `svgs` as well but these are dynamic. We need to change the background and border color attaching classes to some elements inside of the svg, so they will end up being a component anyway

Exactly, I think this looks way better. Also, I believe you can replace the `.map()` followed by `.flat()` by just using `.flatMap()`

`.flatMap((lateral, index) => createSpreadsLateralLineMarkers(lateral, index))`
I believe that's fine. We're doing that for the `LoadingPlusCircle` svg.

pull.title: [IMERC-432]: Loading Optimization Enhancement
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Remove modal that shows "Route is optimizing..."
- Show a "locked" grey accordion panel when the given route is optimizing
- Make an optimizing route un-editable

## Acceptance criteria:

- [x] User clicks optimize, then the route will change to greyed out/loading state
- [x] User clicks optimize, then the route will be locked and can perform no more edits
- [x] User clicks optimize, then the user should be able to continue modifying other draft + optimized routes
- [x] The greyed out/locked accordion panel should have loading spinner and cancel button, and be collapsed
- [x] The greyed out/locked accordion panel should remain collapsed until finished optimizing or user clicks cancel button
- [x] When the optimization completes, a toast message should be shown

## Context:
[[IMERC-432]](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-432): FE - implement optimization in left navigation

comments.body:
That documentation says that the `getDashArray` is removed from `PathLayer` and moved in `PathLayerExtension`.

> Note: In v8.0, the getDashArray and dashJustified props are removed from the PathLayer and moved into this extension.

+      new PathStyleExtension({ dash: true, getDashArray: (data: any) => data.dashArray }),

comments.body: I'm not sure I follow? TypeScript is alerting me that `getDashArray` isn't a property on `PathLayer`, which makes sense, given that in the `PathLayerExtension` documentation it states it's been removed from `PathLayer` and moved to `PathLayerExtension`. What's the problem moving into `PathLayerExtension`? It doesn't break the dashed line.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -33,7 +33,8 @@ export const createPathLayer = (
     widthMinPixels: 2,
     getWidth: (data) => data.width,
     getColor: (data) => data.color,
-    getDashArray: (data: any) => data.dashArray,
-    extensions: [new PathStyleExtension({ dash: true })],
+    extensions: [
+      new PathStyleExtension({ dash: true, getDashArray: (data: any) => data.dashArray }),
+    ],
comments.body:
We agree that `getDashArray` is not part of `PathLayer` anymore, that's fine. Documentation says that these properties are now only taken into consideration if using the `PathLayerExtension`.

"_When added to a layer via the extensions prop, the PathStyleExtension adds the following properties to the layer_"

If you check DeckGL's code, this is how the constructor for `PathStyleExtension` looks like:

```
  constructor({dash = false, offset = false, highPrecisionDash = false} = {}) {
    super({dash: dash || highPrecisionDash, offset, highPrecisionDash});
  }
```

Aligned with the documentation, only those 3 properties should be part of the constructor.

TypeScript definitions are also not official, as it seems DeckGL doesn't have any typings so we shouldn't expect them to be perfect. We had this same issue with Johann and we decided to `ts-ignore` for now as there's no way to correctly set the type.

The problem with this is that even though it works now, although I haven't tested it, it might break in the future as this is simply not what the library expects.
this seems to be the only way to get the most up-to-date lateral information when inside of `optimizeAllRouteSegments`. Without this, the function seems to read an old version of the redux state.
typo
spread operator is not needed here

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -98,6 +103,7 @@ export const ProjectMap: FC<ProjectMapProps> = ({
       currentPointInEditMode,
       currentSpreadInEditMode,
       currentActiveTab,
+      route: storedRoute,
comments.body: No need to rename the variable as `route` is not being used
It's probably better to have this check inside the `setMarkerType` function
Multiline if statements should be wrapped with curly braces
Should we add a comment above? // Used within optimizeAllRouteSegments to keep track of updated version of laterals, or something like that
Why `element` instead of `route`? I feel like route makes more sense as we're looking inside a `routes` array
`optimizationIdToAdd` should be an id (number) as the name indicates, not an array.
ES6 methods are usually preferred. We can write this as `routes[routeIndex].optimizationIds = [...optimizationIds, optimizationIdToAdd];`

This should probably be `removeRouteInOptimizationMode` to follow the naming of the function above. Also, its argument should be `routeIdInOptimizationMode`, again, based on the function above.

Function should also be wrapped in curly braces

We should probably name this `routeOptimizationStatus` to better differentiate between route and individual segment optimizations.

We can also assign a default value, probably `"success"` and only change it on error or on cancel. This will automatically type the variable as `string`

All of these conditions (including the "success" one below) won't happen at the same time so it would be better to use `if/else`. Seeing as `"success"` will probably be the most common option, we can move to the top to allow for early returning
We already have the Ids being optimized in the state above, why do we need this?
This should be `routeId` as we're passing down the id of the route we want to know is optimizing. This is also how we usually name our function arguments
This should be named `LoadingOptimizationProps`
In all places where this component is being called we're passing down a `string` as title, so the prop should probably be typed as such
The dependency here should just be `routeOptimization`
`route` is not being used, no need to rename

I had the dependency originally as `[routeOptimization]` and it didn't work. It only seems to work when I specify the `routeOptimization?.optimizationIds`.

I'll change this from `[routeOptimization?.optimizationIds.length]` to `[routeOptimization?.optimizationIds]`
@zackcarlson that's kinda cool, thanks for the detailed explanation!

This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
- The recommended version is **17 versions** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **21 days ago**, on 2021-08-12.
Release notes
Package name: @deck.gl/extensions
  • 8.5.3 - 2021-08-12
    • Scatterplot layer: antialising prop (#6081)
    • Check for correct layerName when highlighting in MVTLayer (#6062)
  • 8.5.2 - 2021-08-03
    • Fix MapboxLayer React integration (#6053)

    • Fix: MVT update min/maxZoom props (#6040)
    • improve GeoJsonLayer auto highlighting logic (#6018)
    • TextLayer supports backgroundPadding as vec4 (#6017)

    • Bump luma.gl (#6014)

    • fix picking with binary geojson (#6011)

    • Avoid onError call if context is lost after finalization (#5992)
    • Bump math.gl to 3.5.3 (#5994)
    • Binary MVTLayer returns geometry when picking (#5965)
    • Bump dependencies (#5990)
    • Provide default skirt height for tiled TerrainLayer (#5982)

    • Bump math.gl to 3.5.1 (#5972)
    • Billboard prop for Scatterplot layer (#5956)
    • Enforce OrbitView orbitAxis prop (#5962)
    • Add fadeTrail prop to TripLayer (#5921)
  • 8.5.0-beta.1 - 2021-07-06
    • Bump dependencies (#5951)
    • MVTLayer and TerrainLayer switch to use worker-only loaders (#5946)
    • update bundle config (#5949)
    • Bump loaders to 3.0.0-beta.6 (#5943)
    • MVTLayer use all loaders (#5934)
    • CARTO module: bearer token always in header (#5933)
    • TileLayer: add zoomOffset prop (#5896)
    • Don't Use tileSize for Determining z of Tile Indexing in InfoVis (#5895)
    • CARTO module: rename code from cloud-native to carto3 (#5932)
    • tile-3d: update with new loaders version (#5920)
    • Fix: Initialize mapsUrl in cloud native (#5868)
    • Upgrade ocular-dev-tools (#5910)

pull.title: [IMERC-459] Auto-generate Spreads
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Adds spreads to sidebar
- Generates spreads with a length of 100 miles each for each optimized route
- General improvements that improve readability and reduce clutter
- Adds utils for ProjectMap to handle PathLayers creation, idea is to reutilize this for main route and laterals

## Context
[IMERC-459]

comments.body: not for now but I think we should have a `styles/colors.ts` file for these colors (even "white") and we could try to have naming conventions that don't relate to the actual color.

This is definitely better. Although I feel we can simplify it even more by using `currentActiveTab` inside the `renderMainLine` and `renderLateralLines` functions.

Instead of receiving a `forceInactive` arg, we can do something like: `const isCurrentRouteInEditMode = currentRouteInEditMode === 0 && currentActiveTab === 0;`

We would then be able to show either `modifiedOptimizedLayer` or `spreadsPathLayers` based on the `currentActiveTab`

I'm not sure about using the ternary conditional to build the pathLayers array because I believe we will need to go back to an if/switch statement when we include the Laydowns tab.

However, I agree with removing `forceInactive` arg and evaluating the condition inside of `renderMainLine` and `renderLateralLines`

I will also use either a constant or an enum to make the if condition more readable eg:

```
if (currentActiveTab === RoutePlannerTabs.SPREADS) {
...      
}
```
I'm ok with a switch or if version, what I don't like is to push thing to an array for later return.

To reduce the lines of code in this file and to match the good convention of creating the path layers elsewhere (ie `createSpreadsPathLayers`), I suggest we potentially move `renderMainLine` and `renderLateralLines` to `utils/project-map/routes` (or something like that).
`params` should be a dependency of the `useEffect` or better still `routeId`
why are we pushing `undefined` into an array? `[undefined]`

Because we need to return items in the same order that we input them. 

This method receives an array of spreads and returns an array that contains the projections of each of the spreads on the initial array.

If for any reason we can't project a spread, the returned array has `undefined` on the same index of that spread
Good suggestion, I reused most of the duplicated code on a new commit

I accidentally removed my comment here. Absolutely! I didn't want to add that here as to keep the PR as short as possible, but moving forward it would be great to move some stuff around for both the RoutePlanner and the ProjectMap.

ok, that make sense, no need to do anything then but I really don't get the idea of assigning `undefined` instead of `null`, I saw the same on a few places, I don't think there's a good reason for a developer to ever assign `undefined` to something.
Not saying we _should_ move this to `src/entities` but all of our `enums` live in there. `import { RoutePlannerSidebarTab } from '@/molecules';` makes it look like we're importing a component.
We can probably have this as `ROUTE_DETAILS = "Route Details"`, same for the others. Doing so will avoid us having to then create a new object with their names.
If you agree with the change above, we should then rename `tabIndex` to `tab` as we're now referring to the actual tab rather than its index.
Yeah, it doesn't seem right that this is inside of molecules but I wouldn't like it to be on entities either since it is not part of our business model.

pull.title: Rename all index files not being used as barrels
pull.body: ## Changes: - Rename all index files not being used as barrels ## Context: Currently searching for files is not really optimal as you rarely get the file you're looking for as the first option. Also, as most of our files are named `index`, it's hard to keep track of the currently open files. By renaming every component to have the same name as its parent directory we avoid both of this issues. OLD VERSION NEW VERSION

pull.title: bugfix/[IMERC-501]: Update path lines on redo, undo, and add point
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Adds a `useEffect` in the `ProjectMap.tsx` that updates the view state of the `DeckGL` map when `segments` or `laterals` change

## Context:
[[IMERC-501]](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-501)
The line path isn't drawn until the user interacts with the map (drags, moves, or zooms). This bug occurs when clicking undo, redo, or initially adding an endpoint to a fresh route.

 ## Screenshots/videos:
<details>
<summary>Click to expand/collapse</summary>

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/131420819-b5c0f3fe-f500-4bd9-bc88-22dcb9a3fc59.mov
</details>

comments.body: Any particular reason why `AdminRoles`, `InviteUsersSlideOver` and `PageHeader` snapshots are deleted?
I believe this is a way to forcefully fix the issue but we are not addressing the root of the problem. I'm fine with approving this solution for now, though.

I think the root of the problem is that the state of the map isn't updating, which might be a side effect of us controlling the state of the map with the `onViewStateChange` function. If we don't use this function, I think the internal state of the map will be updated by deck.gl on its own. 

The [documentation](https://deck.gl/docs/api-reference/core/deck) says:
> If initialViewState is provided, the Deck component will track view state changes from any attached controller using internal state, with initialViewState as its initial view state. This is the easiest way to control the camera.
> 
> If the initialViewState prop changes, the internally tracked view state will be updated to match the new "initial" view state.
> 
> Notes:
> 
> The onViewStateChange callback will still be called, if provided.
> If the viewState prop is supplied by the application, the supplied viewState will always be used, overriding the Deck component's internal view state.
> In simple applications, use of the initialViewState prop can avoid the need to track the view state in the application.
> One drawback of using initialViewState for reactive/functional applications is that the Deck component becomes more stateful.

For some reason, the snapshots were failing and I'm not sure why. Sean reported that these specific components were failing in the build, and it was because of their mismatched snapshots. Hence, why I deleted them to push these changes up (not a good reason, but that's the reason).

We shouldn't delete tests because they are failing, we should investigate and see why it's happening and try to solve it. If the issue is snapshots being different then we can always re-generate them.

Agreed with Johann here, this doesn't really solve the underlying issue. I think we can also safely assume that this bug was introduced with the addition of the `modifiedOptimizedLayer`. We should probably try and see what's wrong with it before taking the easy path.

comments.body:
perhaps:
```suggestion
          {enabledDescription || enabledDefaultDescription}
```
?
can we move this to a variable? in the same fashion as `routeHasUnoptimizedSegments`? ~something like `segmentHasOptmizedPoints`?~ see my comment below

maybe it's better to have a variable for this so it's clear why it is disabled? btw I think this kind of functions should live on `utils/` so we can reuse instead of always asking the same things

```javascript
const hasDraftSegment = segments.some((segment) => segment.optimizedPoints.length === 0)
```

@cakekindel let's not do that, let's not call functions for rendering components if something needs to be a component then let's just move that to a new file inside the folder and render that component directly.
Nothing wrong with calling a function although i agree that its a smell that it should be a separate component

Sure you can memoize those and you're fine but whenever you see a `renderSomething` function you need to ask why is that not a component? I prefer to avoid those as much as possible, there's just not any good reason to have them. 

Being able to see the return method of a component and immediately understand what's going on is quite valuable for a frontend engineer, having three function calls without any arguments just make everything more confusing. On the other hand having `<Accordion options={amazingOptions} handleChange={changeTheWorld} />` gives a lot of clarity that is missing on the `renderSsomething` approach.
we can change this test label to `shows the disabled text prop if disabled`

pull.title: Fix FileInput types
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Removes `UseFormRegistraterReturn` from prop types 
- Removes asserting `files[0]` as `any`

## Context:
Asserting as `any` was a temporary fix while we investigated what was causing the issue. This has been now resolved with the changes listed above.

Package name: @hookform/resolvers
  • 2.7.1 - 2021-08-04

    2.7.1 (2021-08-04)

    Performance Improvements

    • typanion: reduce bundle size (#192) (4309d1c)
  • 2.7.0 - 2021-07-31

    2.7.0 (2021-07-31)

    Features

    • typanion resolver (72bd952)
    import { useForm } from 'react-hook-form';
import { typanionResolver } from '@ hookform/resolvers/typanion';
import * as t from 'typanion';

const isUser = t.isObject({
  username: t.applyCascade(t.isString(), [t.hasMinLength(1)]),
  age: t.applyCascade(t.isNumber(), [t.isInteger(), t.isInInclusiveRange(1, 100)]),
});

const App = () => {
  const {
    register,
    handleSubmit,
    formState: { errors },
  } = useForm({
    resolver: typanionResolver(isUser),
  });

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit((d) => console.log(d))}>
      <input {...register('name')} />
      {errors.name?.message && <p>{errors.name?.message}</p>}
      <input type="number" {...register('age')} />
      {errors.age?.message && <p>{errors.age?.message}</p>}
      <input type="submit" />
    </form>
  );
};
  • 2.6.1 - 2021-07-13
