pull.title: [IMERC-422-423-425]: Error on laterals
pull.body:
IMERC-422
IMERC-423 
IMERC-425

PR related to disconnected laterals.

Disconnected Lateral: Lateral which start point is not in any of the optimized segments of the main route.

- Shows errors on map when on lateral becomes disconnected
- Compute which laterals disconnect when main route is modified
- Compute which laterals are disconnected when fetching route from backend
- Shows error on sidebar when on lateral becomes disconnected
- Disabled dragging for disconnected laterals when main route is not optimized since there will be no route to snap to
- Show button to connect a lateral (only available if at least one segment of the main route is optimized)

comments.body:
This seems to be pretty much the same as `AddGeoPoint` but with a red border. It's probably better to reuse that component.

Also, as this is being render after mapping the `pointList` array inside the `Points` component, it should have a key, otherwise you get an error in the console.

According to the designs there should also be a higher margin between the button and the title of the accordion.
This might not be necessary as dispatching the `updateStoredRoute` action should then update both `segments` and `laterals` which should then trigger the `useEffect` at line 695.
We shouldn't manipulate the state directly. We can spread `localLaterals[lateralIndex]` on line 477 into `updatedLateral` and then change the `isConnected` value in there.

It's probably better to disable the button if this happens instead of returning inside here. I was just testing and I kept pressing the button but it did nothing because my main line wasn't optimized. If this was disabled instead, I would have understood that something was first needed to be able to use the button.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -3,4 +3,5 @@ export enum MarkerType {
   ROUTE_ACTIVE_PIN_INACTIVE = 'ROUTE_ACTIVE_PIN_INACTIVE',
   ROUTE_ACTIVE_PIN_ACTIVE = 'ROUTE_ACTIVE_PIN_ACTIVE',
   ROUTE_INACTIVE_PIN_INACTIVE = 'ROUTE_INACTIVE_PIN_INACTIVE',
+  ERROR = 'ERROR',
comments.body: Should this maybe be something like ROUTE_ERROR_PIN_ERROR to follow the naming structure?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -3,4 +3,5 @@ export enum MarkerType {
   ROUTE_ACTIVE_PIN_INACTIVE = 'ROUTE_ACTIVE_PIN_INACTIVE',
   ROUTE_ACTIVE_PIN_ACTIVE = 'ROUTE_ACTIVE_PIN_ACTIVE',
   ROUTE_INACTIVE_PIN_INACTIVE = 'ROUTE_INACTIVE_PIN_INACTIVE',
+  ERROR = 'ERROR',
comments.body: Wanted to make it generic enough since we will be using this type of marker for all kinds of errors but it makes sense to be inline with other names. Will update it.
[new commit](https://github.com/iMercatus/imercata-web/pull/282/commits/cb9dbba20e30eba931d1554e1d8c41aa483df1a3) addresses this
[new commit](https://github.com/iMercatus/imercata-web/pull/282/commits/cb9dbba20e30eba931d1554e1d8c41aa483df1a3) addresses this
To avoid the `if/else` here we can set `let pathLineColor = ERROR_ROUTE_RED` by default and only check then if it's connected.
You should use `updatedLateral` on line 473, otherwise we're still manipulating the state directly which is what we don't want to do.
You deleted the wrong line, I meant that manually updating `localLaterals` might not be needed as they should be automatically updated after dispatching the `updateStoreRoute` action.
Would showing a disabled cursor fix this? I though everything related w/ dealing with laterals was going to be disabled when the main route is not optimized but that is beyond the scope of this task
If we were to use the `AddGeoPoint` component as proposed on another comment then we can use this same condition as the value of the `disabled` prop which already handles the different stylings.
yep, my bad, fixing it

pull.title: [IMERC-422-423] Laterals error state
pull.body:
IMERC-422
IMERC-423 

PR related to disconnected laterals.

Disconnected Lateral: Lateral which start point is not in any of the optimized segments of the main route.

- Shows errors on map when on lateral becomes disconnected
- Compute which laterals disconnect when main route is modified
- Compute which laterals are disconnected when fetching route from backend
- Shows error on sidebar when on lateral becomes disconnected
- Disabled dragging for disconnected laterals when main route is not optimized since there will be no route to snap to

comments.body: minor code reuse, you have a const on line 190 that is the same expression

could be a little more concise
```suggestion
      const pathLineColor = !lateral.isConnected ? ERROR_ROUTE_RED
                          : isCurrentRouteInEditMode ? ACTIVE_ROUTE_CYAN
                          : INACTIVE_ROUTE_GRAY;
```
should this block the updates? could we wrap this in a promise and run this computation and the updates in parallel?
@cakekindel @johannmorales it is clear from a React standpoint (most projects would do that) let's keep the `&&` instad of a ternary.

pull.title: Segments implementation
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Converts the entire Route Planner to use Segments
- Routes are now split into segments, being able to modify them individually
- Optimizing a route will now optimize all currently unoptimized segments in parallel
- If modifying an optimized route, only the affected segment will go back into draft mode
- FE now updates BE with the new optimized points after optimizing a route
- If the route has already been created in the BE, every following change to its geometry will update BE
- Fixes issue where draft laterals disappeared after optimizing a lateral

## Context:
[[IMERC-377](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-377)]
[[IMERC-410](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-410)]
[[IMERC-443](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-443)]
[[IMERC-444](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-444)]

## Screenshots:
![Screen Shot 2021-08-24 at 20 58 03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8879212/130704928-e04e780d-b3a7-4752-b814-62ba6865bccd.png)

comments.body: If you've optimized a lateral, and then refresh the page, the call to `fetchLaterals` brings back the lateral without its' `optimizedPoints`. This leads me to believe when calling `updateCurrentLateral`, it actually doesn't update it on the backend.
Will `lateralId` ever be **0**? If so, we may need to change this to `if (lateralId !== undefined)` or `if (Number.isInteger(lateralId)`

Not an issue, just adding this comment to add visibility to this change.

I really like the new names, they are more readable and fit well together.  Will make sure to keep future prop/params naming as clean as these ones.

Before optimizing we always either create or update the route/lateral. Due to this, the arguments for `routeId` and `lateralId` that the `optimizeAllRouteSegments` function receive will always have a valid value returned by BE (not null and bigger than 0).
Completely agree with you in here, small changes like these might not seem necessary but they really end up improving the developer experience. It's cool that you noticed, thanks for pointing it out!

minor code reuse, comparing positions
```suggestion
const positionsEq: (a?: Position, b?: Position) => boolean = a && b && a[0] === b[0] && a[1] === b[1];
export const getUniqueUserDefinedPoints = (segments: Array<Segment>) =>
  segments
    .flatMap((segment) => segment.userDefinedPoints)
    .filter((point, index, array) => !positionsEq(point.coordinates, array[index - 1].coordinates));
```

depends on above suggestion
```suggestion
export const getUniqueOptimizedPoints = (segments: Array<Segment>) =>
  segments
    .flatMap((segment) => segment.optimizedPoints)
    .filter((position, index, array) => !positionsEq(position, array[index - 1]));
```
I tried this but something's breaking. I like your solution though so I'll refactor this to remove duplicated code. Thanks!

pull.title: [IMERC-483] Made phone number static
pull.body:
Currently phone numbers are generated using the Chance.js library. According to the documentation of this library it generates phone numbers that conforms to NANP (North American Numbering Plan) for a proper US phone number. However, when using the library we realized that it is generating phone numbers that are not valid under NANP. These non-valid phone numbers are rejected by the registration page validations.

Solution: turn the phone number use for testing static. It does not affect the goal of the test, that is to make sure the registration process works and the user is able to complete steps 1, 2, and 3.

pull.title: bugfix: delete lateral from backend
pull.body:
[IMERC-408](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-408)

### api/routes.ts

- Create `deleteLateral` API function

### RoutePlanner.tsx

- Update `handleDeleteLateral` to use the API call `deleteLateral` for existing lateral on BE

comments.body: This should now be an `async` function

As to not repeat ourselves, we should check for the opposite condition. If there's a `currentRouteId` and the `lateral.id !== 0` then we should `await deleteLateral(projectId, currentRouteId, lateral.id);`

This will allow us to keep the function as it was before, and only call the API if needed.

Does the API return anything after deleting? If it does, then we should type the response, otherwise we can just await the call and not return anything as done on the `cancelRouteOptimization` or `cancelLateralOptimization`
This is being called twice.

pull.title: bugfix: Phone number validation
pull.body:
[IMERC-265](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-265)

### UserRegistration

- Format phone number as it is typed
- International format on backend submit

comments.body: Checking for `registrationBody.user` is not needed as we're spreading `registration.user` into it, so it will have the same value, making the extra check redundant.

Why are we formatting the phone number again? I'm not sure it makes sense to format the number as the user types and then change its format before sending it to BE. If we show the number somewhere else, BE would return an unformatted version which would make no sense to the user.

The backend expects it to  be formatted as an international number, but the user can input numbers formatted as national (US) numbers. 

International number: +1 749 239 123 (Valid on the backend, User doesn't always input numbers like this)
US national number: (749) 239 123 (Not valid on the backend, User's common way to input phone numbers)

One approach would be to modify the backend validation, what are your thoughts on this? @msallent
Agreed on aligning with BE to make sure the value that the user types is the value that we're storing.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,7 @@ export const userProperties = z.object({
   phone: z
     .string()
     .refine(trim, 'Please, type your phone')
-    .refine(
-      (phone) => isValidPhoneNumber(phone) && isValidPhoneNumber(phone, 'US'),
-      'Expected format: +49 1111 2222',
-    ),
+    .refine((phone) => isValidPhoneNumber(phone, 'US'), 'Expected format: (651) 646-2442'),
comments.body:
I think we need to separate validation into two different steps:
- Validate that the number is valid
- Validate that the format is the expected one

Doing so will avoid situations like this, where the error is probably that the number is invalid but the error message says that the format is wrong, which is not.

![Screen Shot 2021-08-17 at 17 56 06](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8879212/129799558-59263265-d1d9-4e49-a2bf-62ee25882d63.png)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,7 @@ export const userProperties = z.object({
   phone: z
     .string()
     .refine(trim, 'Please, type your phone')
-    .refine(
-      (phone) => isValidPhoneNumber(phone) && isValidPhoneNumber(phone, 'US'),
-      'Expected format: +49 1111 2222',
-    ),
+    .refine((phone) => isValidPhoneNumber(phone, 'US'), 'Expected format: (651) 646-2442'),
comments.body:
Since we are formatting as we type, it doesn't make sense to validate the format. 

I'll change the error message to show that we are validating whether it is a valid phone number or not, not the format

pull.title: [Snyk] Upgrade @reduxjs/toolkit from 1.5.1 to 1.6.1
pull.body:
Snyk has created this PR to upgrade @reduxjs/toolkit from 1.5.1 to 1.6.1.

![merge advice](https://app.snyk.io/badges/merge-advice/?package_manager=npm&package_name=@reduxjs/toolkit&from_version=1.5.1&to_version=1.6.1&pr_id=6fcdb8e4-9445-476b-8e92-063616815beb&visibility=true&has_feature_flag=false) :sparkles: Snyk has automatically assigned this pull request, [set who gets assigned](https://app.snyk.io/org/imercatus/project/95fba3d2-9a74-46ba-a36d-c4f2cdc496fa/settings/integration?utm_source=github&utm_medium=upgrade-pr/settings/integration). :information_source: Keep your dependencies up-to-date. This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
- The recommended version is **8 versions** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **a month ago**, on 2021-07-17.
Release notes
Package name: @reduxjs/toolkit
  • 1.6.1 - 2021-07-17

    This release improves several edge cases in RTK Query behavior and implementation, deprecates a lesser-used API, and reverts an internal compatability change from 1.6.

    Changelog

    RTK Query Tweaks

    We've made several small tweaks to the RTK Query implementation:

    • fetchBaseQuery now provides a more meaningful error if the response can't be parsed successfully
    • fetchBaseQuery has been tweaked to always read fetch from the global scope, rather than closing over it at creation time. This improves usage with test tools that mock or override fetch at the system level, such as Mirage.
    • The skipToken symbol is now created using Symbol.for(), to get a consistent reference
    • API slices now warn if you try to add more than one reducer with the same reducerPath name
    • An internal hook usage was tweaked to avoid the "don't call useLayoutEffect on the server" warning being printed in SSR

    Also, mutations no longer track the originalArgs value in the store. That value is needed to re-run queries, but since mutations are not re-run, it wasn't needed. This change resolves cases where users were passing a non-serializable value as the mutation argument and then seeing warnings about it being put into the store.

    Technically, this is a breaking change (removes a store property what would have been returned by a selector), but it is a necessary bugfix, and it does not appear anyone was actively using that property. So, we're keeping this as a patch release.

    Generally, the information removed is still available as:

    • a property on the promise returned by dispatch
    • part of the thunk action meta
    • return value of the useMutation hook

    Other Changes

    The typings for createAction and createAsyncThunk have been tweaked to avoid lint warnings about "unbound methods".

    The exported version of getDefaultMiddleware is now marked as deprecated, and will be removed in a future 2.0 release. Use the function passed as the middleware callback instead, which has the correct store types anyway.

    In 1.6, we moved the Immer enableES5 plugin init call from index.ts to be inside of createReducer instead, in an effort to maybe save a few bytes for some users. This has caused some issues for users who still support IE11, possibly due to build config issues. Realistically, we expect that everyone who uses RTK will be calling createReducer, createSlice, or createApi at some point, so there's no real situations where this wouldn't be called anyway. So, we've moved the enableES5 call back to index.ts for consistency. In a future 2.0 release, we will remove that call entirely, and users that still support IE11 will need to call that themselves.

    Changes

    • Error handling of fetchBaseQuery (#1250 - @ phryneas)
    • Warn on duplicate reducerPath (#1252 - @ phryneas)
    • Deprecate getDefaultMiddleware export (#1258 - @ Shrugsy)
    • Typing for unbound functions (#1263 - @ ajcrites)
    • Prevent closing over fetch (#1267 - @ Shrugsy)
    • Put enableES5 back in index.ts (#1305 - @ komar94)
    • Use Symbol.for('skipToken') (#1317 - @ phryneas)
    • Remove originalArgs (#1318 - @ phryneas)
    • Call useIsomorphicLayoutEffect to fix warnings (#1319 - @ markerikson)
  • 1.6.0 - 2021-06-07
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-rc.1 - 2021-06-03

    This release candidate finalizes the upcoming RTK Query APIs. It adds new options to createAsyncThunk for adding meta fields to thunk-dispatched actions, updates the createApi lifecycle handlers to pass through those meta fields, and removes fields that were deprecated during the alpha process. We've also fleshed out the RTKQ preview docs with significant new content.

    This should be the final preview before the RTK 1.6 final release, barring any unforeseen last-minute bugs. (Note: This is the same content as rc.0, but we found a bug in our build process that had wrong output in that release. Hopefully no more issues!)

    The preview docs are located at https://deploy-preview-1016--redux-starter-kit-docs.netlify.app .

    Installation:

    npm i @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

yarn add @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

    Changelog

    Async Thunk meta Support

    createAsyncThunk automatically generates action creators and action types, and then automatically dispatches those actions during execution. This simplifies the process of creating and using thunks, but like all abstractions, also limits flexibility.

    One limitation has been that there was no way to customize the meta field to the actions generated by createAsyncThunk, and some users needed to add additional metadata to actions for use by other middleware.

    We've updated createAsyncThunk to allow adding additional contents to meta. The approach varies based on the action type:

    • pending: there is a new getPendingMeta({arg, requestId}) callback that can be passed as part of the createAsyncThunk options object. This is necessary because the pending action is dispatched before the payload creator is even called.
    • fulfilled: there is a new fulfillWithMeta utility in the payload creator's thunkApi object, which can be used instead of returning the payload directly: return fulfillWithMeta(actualPayload, meta)
    • rejected: the existing rejectWithValue utility now also accepts a meta argument: return rejectWithValue(failedPayload, meta)

    API Lifecycle meta Support

    The createApi cache lifecycle callbacks like onCacheEntryAdded now make the meta field available as part of the promise result, such as cacheDataLoaded.

    Code Cleanup and Types Tweaks

    The fields such as onStart and onSuccess that were deprecated in earlier alphas have been removed.

    The now-unused ApiWithInjectedEndpoints type was removed.

    Various APIs that accept arrays were updated to mark those array parameters as readonly, to help indicate that they shouldn't be mutated, and to ensure that arrays marked as const can be accepted.

    The ApiModules type was modified to prevent a inferred type of this node exceeds the maximum length the compiler will serialize TS error.

    Docs Updates

    We've updated to Docusaurus 2.0-beta.0, which includes Webpack 5. No visible change for you, but faster CI builds for us thanks to build artifact caching! (Our docs builds dropped from around 7 minutes each build down to around 25 seconds, thanks to only changed files being rebuilt.)

    We've also completed filling out the RTK Query API docs.

    Changes

    Code

    • Remove upcoming alpha.3 deprecations (#1052 - @ phryneas)
    • createAsyncThunk: support for meta (#1083 - @ phryneas)
    • Add baseQueryMeta to thunks, meta to lifecycle results (#1083 - @ phryneas)
    • Remove ApiWithInjectedEndpoints references (#1112 - @ msutkowski)
    • Add readonly to array-type function params (#1113 - @ phryneas)
    • remove Id to force lazy evaluation of API type (#1116 - @ phryneas)

    Docs

    • Wayyyy too many docs PRs to even try to list here :) (@ Shrugsy)
    • Wayyyy too many examples moved from sandboxes to even try to list here :) (@ msutkowski)
    • Match redux config for docusaurus webpack v5 (#1086 - @ msutkowski)
    • Some assorted content tweaks (@ markerikson)

    v1.6.0-beta.0...v1.6.0-rc.1

  • 1.6.0-rc.0 - 2021-06-03

    This release is broken due to a build misconfiguration - please see rc.1 instead:

    https://github.com/reduxjs/redux-toolkit/releases/tag/v1.6.0-rc.1

  • 1.6.0-beta.0 - 2021-05-22
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-alpha.2 - 2021-04-26

    This release fixes a bug with RTK Query cache invalidation, and exposes the useLazyQuerySubscription hook.

    Installation:

    npm i @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

yarn add @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

    Changelog

    Invalidation Bugfix

    We saw that RTK Query cache invalidation was actually broken in alpha.1. After investigation, it looks like TypeScript was outputting incorrect code for looping over a set.values() iterator. We've tweaked the logic to work around that.

    Please upgrade to this release ASAP, as invalidation is a key part of RTK Query's functionality.

    useLazyQuerySubscription

    The useLazyQuerySubscription hook was documented, but wasn't actually being included in the output. We've fixed that.

    Additional Build Tweaks

    We're still fiddling with the combination of ESBuild and TypeScript for our recently updated build chain, and have flipped a couple more switches in the process. Should be no user-visible difference.

    Changes

    • Expose useLazyQuerySubscription for endpoints ( #1017 - @ Shrugsy)
    • Fix bad transpilation of set iteration breaking invalidation (#1020 - @ markerikson)

    v1.6.0-alpha.1...v1.6.0-alpha.2

  • 1.6.0-alpha.1 - 2021-04-24
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-alpha.0 - 2021-04-04
    Read more
  • 1.5.1 - 2021-03-26

pull.title: fix: api proxy should follow redirects
pull.body:
[IMERC-278](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-278) Ensure iMercata Swagger docs are accessible

one big contentious change that is worth calling out: the swagger docs only work if the URL has a trailing slash, and by default Next 308 redirects to the same route without a trailing slash. Next's trailing slash behavior can only be "enforce trailing **or** enforce no trailing" application-wide, so to move forward I toggled the behavior to "enforce trailing." :confused:

Looking for buy-in on the route behavior ~and there will be a sister PR in the backend to add authentication in front of swagger docs.~

pull.title: [IMERC-378] Undo/Redo
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Adds new styles to Button component
- Move most of the RoutePlanner's state to Redux
- Adds undo/redo buttons as part of Map Overlay
- Adds complete undo/redo functionality that updates on each route change (point moved, point added, point deleted, optimized route, lateral point moved, lateral point added, lateral point deleted, optimized lateral)
- Removes `type` from `Point` interface. Marker types are now handled in a declarative way based on the `currentRouteInEditMode` and `currentPointInEditMode`
- Removes `mapMode` from `ProjectMap`. Draft or optimized lines are now rendered based on the current available data.
- Fixes [[IMERC-409]](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-409): lateral now switches to draft mode after moving one of its points while on optimized state
- Fixes [[IMERC-413]](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-413): markers are now always draggable, independently of current route state

## Context:
[[IMERC-378]](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-378)

comments.body: Yeah, I'm not sure why that's there. Good catch.
The user still needs to be able to click on the draw button and enter `drawMode`. With this simplified version, you'd never actually get to set the mode to be `drawMode`.

> The user still needs to be able to click on the draw button and enter drawMode. With this simplified version, you'd never actually get to set the mode to be drawMode.

Same as my previous reply, but with `deleteMode`.
Makes sense.
Yes, the name should be updated to better reflect what it is

I don't see how not using an object is confusing. The editor will always tell you what's expected. The function not working correctly when passing down data in the wrong order is expected because you're assigning values to the wrong arguments.

This is one of the main reasons we use TypeScript for, if you pass down the arguments in the wrong order TS will complain because there will be type conflicts.

I'll say it again, there's nothing wrong with using objects as arguments, I just don't see them being useful for this case as we're just adding noise. There's also the issue of consistency, there are functions inside this same file which don't receive an object while others do. We should aim to be as consistent as possible and only break this rule if really needed.

By adding the `?` after `route` you're checking if `route` exists, not if `isOverlapped` does.

If `isOverlapped` doesn't have value on all routes that's fine, the point of adding the optional chaining is to prevent calling `undefined.isOverlapped` which would break the application.

This line checks if there are any overlapped modified routes. So if one drawn line overlaps another, we'll assign `isOverlapped: true` to that line. And later, we'll remove it in `removeOverlappedRoutes`.
Oh lord, I am not the sharpest tool in the shed.
As this is a number, we should call this `routeIndex` or whatever's appropiate
This should be `geoJson` as that's how it's written in the setter function
Following convention, this should be `geoJson`
I think with the recent typing changes we might be able to type this correctly
This should use the new type instead of `any`

This entire thing should not live here. The whole point of moving the component to where it belongs to is that everything related to it should move too. By just moving the component but leaving this here we're not really changing anything.

As done for the rest of the components we should pass down each prop individually. If `ModifyToolbar` requires to be able to change the `modificationMode`, then it should receive the `setModificationFunction`, and that function should be passed down through the parent components until reaching it.
This entire thing should live inside the JSX, no reason to store this in a `const`

This can be typed as `(modificationMode: Modification) => void;`. Doing so avoids having to import additional stuff and it's how we typically type these setter functions when being passed down as props.

matias, i've dug into this a bit and see this as some debt that may not make sense to tackle now, the way this is set up is to have the ModifyToolbar bubble up changes to the modification mode to route planner; the component tree:
```
RoutePlanner (passes to Sidebar and ProjectMap)
  |-- ProjectMap (observes modificationMode)
  |-- RoutePlannerSidebar (sets modificationMode, passes to modifytoolbar)
      |-- ModifyToolbar (observes modificationMode)
```
so we would need to alter the way we manage sharing this state in order to remove the tight coupling with setState - which we definitely should do but it's taken me about an hour to get maybe halfway done with this change, and it's pretty large in scope (potentially breaking)

I think that's fine, what I meant is that we should change how this function is typed to be in line with how we usually type setter functions.

`setModificationMode: Dispatch<SetStateAction<Modification>>;`
—>
`setModificationMode: (modificationMode: Modification) => void;`
ah i understand, rather than tightly couple the prop to the idea that it's directly calling `setState` on a parent?

pull.title: Improve Git Hooks
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Adds `lint-staged` to run scripts only on staged files
- Adds `tsc` script to run the TS compiler
- Changes pre-commit hook to run `tsc` and `lint-staged`
- Changes pre-push hook to run `test` and `build`

## Context:
With the current setup we run the linters, tests and build all on the same hook which means that if something fails, we still need to wait until the build finishes, only to then get an error. This usually happens a couple of times, which means that we're building the project several times which can be time consuming.

The goal of this PR is to split up these tasks and have the linters run on pre-commit, meaning we won't be able to commit anything that's broken. Besides ESLint, we also run the TypeScript compiler to make sure there are no TS related issues such as missing props or incompatible types.

Not being able to commit something broken means that we need to fix those issues straight away, including the fix in that same commit. Because of this, when the time to push comes there shouldn't be any errors, requiring the project to be built only once and ultimately, speed up the development flow.

pull.title: [IMERC-366] Center around route
pull.body:
[IMERC-366](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-366)

Centers around the main route, triggered whenever `currentRouteId` changes 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30033816/127422145-8881e580-0c74-4e9a-9eec-582cb5d12bdf.mov

comments.body: Instead of storing the route, we can store a boolean that defines whether the map is centered or not `[isRouteCentered]` which should be `true` by default.
We should remove this entire function.
Instead of setting the route, we can assume after fetching that the route won't be centered, setting `isRouteCentered` to false.
We should set `isRouteCentered` to false here as well.
As props to ProjectMap, we should pass down both the `isRouteCentered` boolean and its setter function as we'll then set it to `true` from within.
`isRouteCentered` should be the dependency here so that after fetching the routes and setting it to `false`, we'll trigger this function to run.
If `isRouteCentered` is `true` we can return as we don't need to do anything.

We now don't have `centerAround` but we have both `userDefinedPoints` and `optimizedPoints`, so we can do something like this which is similar to what was being done on the RoutePlanner.

`const currentRoute =
      optimizedPoints.length > 0
        ? optimizedPoints
        : userDefinedPoints.map(({ coordinates }) => coordinates);`
We should also call here `setIsRouteCentered(true)`

    function Test() {
  const { control, register } = useForm();
  const { fields, append, prepend, remove, swap, move, insert } = useFieldArray({

    name: "test",
  });

  return (

        key={field.id} // important to include key with field's id
        {...register(`test.${index}.value`)}

      />
    ))}
  );
}

pull.title: [IMERC-325]: Delete Lateral
pull.body:
[Story 325](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-325)

### Accordion

- Adds `onDelete?: () => void;` and `dataTestId?: string` to `<Accordion />`
- Updates `Accordion.spec.tsx` to test for `onDelete`

### RoutePlanner

- Adds `handleDeleteLateral: (deleteIndex: number) => void;` to `<RoutePlanner />`

### RoutePlannerSidebar

- Adds `onDeleteLateral: (deleteIndex: number) => void;` to `<RoutePlannerSidebar />`

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/127230896-c6b87b95-96a0-475f-a882-5642d9bc2c7e.mp4

pull.title: [IMERC-385] Route Planner Improvements
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Adds "Route" entity which contains all route-related types and helper functions
- Moves all route-related API calls to a separate file
- Unifies types to prevent duplication and makes them easier to understand
- Moves component specific functions away from parent whenever possible
- Other minor improvements such as renaming variables and moving stuff around

## Context:
[[IMERC-385]](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-385)

pull.title: [IMERC-346] Refresh optimization status fix
pull.body:
[IMERC-346](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-346)

### Refresh optimization status [Modified]
- store `refreshTimeout` id in state 
- cancel `refreshTimeout` on unmount
- if route optimization finished -> remove `refreshTimeout` id and fetch route


### Fetching a route [Modified]
- call `get` ` /projects/projectId/routes/routeId`
- if response has `currentOptimizationId` ->  start polling optimization status

pull.title: Increase Prettier's print width
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Changes .prettierrc file to set `printWidth` to 100
- Formats all files with these new settings

## Context:
The default value of 80 is too narrow, which generates a lot of vertical noise. Extending this limit by 20 characters will allow us to use more horizontal space, reducing file lines and improving readability.

pull.title: [IMERC-322-24]: Add Laterals
pull.body:
Stories: [322](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-322), [323](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-323), [324](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-324)

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/126735982-2ca5489f-6da5-47f3-8af4-3ad1a21fa3fd.mov

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -23,26 +31,40 @@ const INIT_VIEWPORT = {
   pitch: 0,
   zoom: 10,
   minZoom: 0,
-  maxZoom: 12,
+  maxZoom: 14,
comments.body: Is 14 the upper limit of zoom levels (i.e. the map cannot be zoomed in beyond this level)?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -23,26 +31,40 @@ const INIT_VIEWPORT = {
   pitch: 0,
   zoom: 10,
   minZoom: 0,
-  maxZoom: 12,
+  maxZoom: 14,
comments.body: @mfcallahan Yes, that's correct. Otherwise, the user would be able to zoom in beyond the street level, which would then end up looking like nothing; the default map layer shows gray but without any identifying labels or anything (at least in the default `light-v9` Iayer, perhaps it different with a satellite or topographic base layer).

I see that  you have a similar more compact check on `Accordion/index` maybe we can mimic that style here as well instead of the double ternary?

```javascript
return isOpen ? `${contentContainerRef.current?.scrollHeight || minHeight}px` : '0px;
```
We can use constants for these color values
Same as above, we can use use the same constant here
We can use a constant here
Reuse the constant

can we change this to receive an object instead of a number?  imo it will make the code more readable and we won't need to "calculate" which lateral is active (`currentRouteInEditMode === lateralIndex+1`)

e.g 

```
<RoutePlannerSidebar currentRouteInEditMode={{type: 'main' }}/>

<RoutePlannerSidebar currentRouteInEditMode={{type: 'lateral', index: 2} }}/>
```
We can remove the `any` type to have TS infer the corresponding one

Is this some sort of index? If so, can we rename this to `[currentViewportIndex, setCurrentViewportIndex]`? This helps differentiating it from the state one line below. It also indicates in a more clear way that this is supposed to be a number.
We should re use the Route type in here. No need to change it though as this is already handled in the "Route Planner improvements" task, just stating this here for anyone who gets to read it.

Technically, I'll still have to check if the current lateral we're looping over is equal to the currentRouteInEditMode, regardless. So I don't think the change from a number to an object is necessary I'll be doing the same calculation.

pull.title: [IMERC-336]: Render any pre-exisitng routes when a user loads a project
pull.body:
[IMERC-336](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-336)

### RoutePlanner [Modified]
- Able to edit previously created/optimized routes
- Added routeId to path params
- Fetches first project's route by default
- Fetches route when `currentRouteId` changes

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30033816/126172580-e886d2e2-cc9a-4756-ab0a-33ee1ae0d59f.mov

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30033816/126172565-bf0a19e1-b657-4ac2-959d-4b596bab243c.mov

comments.body:
For consistency reasons, I think it might be better to keep using route params rather than query params, so the URL would look like `http://localhost:3001/dashboard/projects/5/routes/:routeId`.

We can then read the `routeId` as done on line 50 with `projectId`. This follows the same URL structure that we've been using and saves us from adding an extra dependency.
We should await the response as done on the `fetchDefaultRouteId` function on line 131.

For the loading animation, Scott shared this the other day: https://www.figma.com/file/3Up295pqOyA4ifY2PUUJUr/iMercata-Tailwind?node-id=4065%3A102908

We can use the Modal component.

pull.title: [IMERC-311]: Add Waypoints to Main Line
pull.body:
[Story 311](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-311)

**Note:** _this PR covers tasks [312](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-312), [313](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-313), [314](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-314), [315](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-315), and [317](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-317). **Also**, this PR is actually only 305 lines of code. The rest is the package`@turf/turf`._

### package.json [Modified]
- Added `@turf/turf` for calculating midpoint (and potentially for future calculations)

### Paragraph [Modified]
- Added `gray-400` to `color` prop

### AddGeoPoint
- Created a molecule similar to `GeoPointDetails`; it's essentially just a button with a `+` character that's disabled/enabled

### Coordinate [Modified]
- Added optional `type: MarkerType` prop to the `Point` type; `MarkerType = 'active' | 'inactive' | 'new'`
- Changed `coordinates: [number, number]` prop value of `Point` type to `coordinates: ProjectMapCoordinates`

### Markers [Modified]
- Changed `markers: Array<ProjectMapCoordinates>` to `markers: Array<MapMarker>`
- Applied `type` to each marker to display different edit mode styles (`'active' | 'inactive' | 'new'`)

### ProjectMap [Modified]
- Changed `userDefinedCoordinates: Array<ProjectMapCoordinates>` to `userDefinedCoordinates: Array<MapMarker>` in order to display different marker styles based on current edit mode

### RoutePlannerSidebar [Modified]
- Added prop `onAddPoint: (point: Point, insertIndex: number) => void;`
- Added prop `onDeletePoint: (deleteIndex: number) => void;`
- Added prop `currPointInEditMode: number;`
- Added prop `onCurrPointInEditModeClick: (pointIndex: number) => void;`
- Added `AddGeoPoint` to molecule
- Used `midpoint` and `point` from `@turf/turf` to determine midpoint of two points
- Made `Optimize Main Line` button stick to bottom

### Sidebar.index.module.css [Modified]
- Made sidebar `wrapper` fixed
- Hide scrollbar on different browsers to prevent squished content

### RoutePlanner[Modified]
- Added state `const [currPointInEditMode, setCurrPointInEditMode] = useState(0);` to watch for the most recently edited point/marker on map
- Added `type: 'new'` to 
```
  const [userDefinedPoints, setUserDefinedPoints] = useState<Array<Point>>([
    { name: 'Start Point', coordinates: [-118, 34], type: 'new' },
  ]);
```
- Changed return type of `userDefinedCoordinates` to `Array<MapMarker>`
- Extended `userDefinedCoordinates` memoized value to listen for changes to `currPointInEditMode`
- Extended `handleOnPointChange` and `handleOnMarkerDragChange` to account for marker style `type` changes
- Created `handleAddPoint` which adds a midpoint to the map and accounts for marker style `type` changes
- Created `handleDeletePoint` which deletes a point from the map and accounts for marker style `type` changes

comments.body: Can these colours be in a constants file or similar?

I believe this molecule will always be used to add a point, right? So the onClick function should be required, otherwise we might have a scenario where we have this molecule somewhere doing nothing and TS not complaining.
Points will always have a MarkerType, should this be required instead?
Markers will always have a certain type. Should this be required, instead?
is `useMemo` needed here?
It makes sense to have MapMarker being the type of an array of Markers, but I find it kind of confusing using this same type for the userDefinedCoordinates.
Also, as to not repeat ourselves, we can create this type as `export type MapMarker = Omit<Point, "name">`.
I think it's better to not use abbreviations, so having `current` instead of `curr`. At least for me, this makes it more readable and has no impact on the final bundled code.
Same comment about abbreviations here, `Index` instead of `Idx` makes more sense for me. `Coordinates` instead of `Coords`, also.
I was re using the `GeoPointDetails` molecule to add the End Point but we can probably now use the new `AddGeoPoint` which makes more sense.
Same comment as above, I find confusing that we're using this type for the userDefineCoordinates. The type itself is correct, it's just the name.
You're right. This can be removed.
Thanks for addressing the above @zackcarlson. We can also remove the default value now that the prop is required.
I believe we don't need to initialize type with a default value as it's now required.

pull.title: [Snyk] Upgrade @reduxjs/toolkit from 1.5.1 to 1.6.0
pull.body:
Snyk has created this PR to upgrade @reduxjs/toolkit from 1.5.1 to 1.6.0.

:sparkles: Snyk has automatically assigned this pull request, [set who gets assigned](https://app.snyk.io/org/imercatus/project/95fba3d2-9a74-46ba-a36d-c4f2cdc496fa/settings/integration?utm_source=github&utm_medium=upgrade-pr/settings/integration). :information_source: Keep your dependencies up-to-date. This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
- The recommended version is **7 versions** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **a month ago**, on 2021-06-07.
Release notes
Package name: @reduxjs/toolkit
  • 1.6.0 - 2021-06-07
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-rc.1 - 2021-06-03

    This release candidate finalizes the upcoming RTK Query APIs. It adds new options to createAsyncThunk for adding meta fields to thunk-dispatched actions, updates the createApi lifecycle handlers to pass through those meta fields, and removes fields that were deprecated during the alpha process. We've also fleshed out the RTKQ preview docs with significant new content.

    This should be the final preview before the RTK 1.6 final release, barring any unforeseen last-minute bugs. (Note: This is the same content as rc.0, but we found a bug in our build process that had wrong output in that release. Hopefully no more issues!)

    The preview docs are located at https://deploy-preview-1016--redux-starter-kit-docs.netlify.app .

    Installation:

    npm i @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

yarn add @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

    Changelog

    Async Thunk meta Support

    createAsyncThunk automatically generates action creators and action types, and then automatically dispatches those actions during execution. This simplifies the process of creating and using thunks, but like all abstractions, also limits flexibility.

    One limitation has been that there was no way to customize the meta field to the actions generated by createAsyncThunk, and some users needed to add additional metadata to actions for use by other middleware.

    We've updated createAsyncThunk to allow adding additional contents to meta. The approach varies based on the action type:

    • pending: there is a new getPendingMeta({arg, requestId}) callback that can be passed as part of the createAsyncThunk options object. This is necessary because the pending action is dispatched before the payload creator is even called.
    • fulfilled: there is a new fulfillWithMeta utility in the payload creator's thunkApi object, which can be used instead of returning the payload directly: return fulfillWithMeta(actualPayload, meta)
    • rejected: the existing rejectWithValue utility now also accepts a meta argument: return rejectWithValue(failedPayload, meta)

    API Lifecycle meta Support

    The createApi cache lifecycle callbacks like onCacheEntryAdded now make the meta field available as part of the promise result, such as cacheDataLoaded.

    Code Cleanup and Types Tweaks

    The fields such as onStart and onSuccess that were deprecated in earlier alphas have been removed.

    The now-unused ApiWithInjectedEndpoints type was removed.

    Various APIs that accept arrays were updated to mark those array parameters as readonly, to help indicate that they shouldn't be mutated, and to ensure that arrays marked as const can be accepted.

    The ApiModules type was modified to prevent a inferred type of this node exceeds the maximum length the compiler will serialize TS error.

    Docs Updates

    We've updated to Docusaurus 2.0-beta.0, which includes Webpack 5. No visible change for you, but faster CI builds for us thanks to build artifact caching! (Our docs builds dropped from around 7 minutes each build down to around 25 seconds, thanks to only changed files being rebuilt.)

    We've also completed filling out the RTK Query API docs.

    Changes

    Code

    • Remove upcoming alpha.3 deprecations (#1052 - @ phryneas)
    • createAsyncThunk: support for meta (#1083 - @ phryneas)
    • Add baseQueryMeta to thunks, meta to lifecycle results (#1083 - @ phryneas)
    • Remove ApiWithInjectedEndpoints references (#1112 - @ msutkowski)
    • Add readonly to array-type function params (#1113 - @ phryneas)
    • remove Id to force lazy evaluation of API type (#1116 - @ phryneas)

    Docs

    • Wayyyy too many docs PRs to even try to list here :) (@ Shrugsy)
    • Wayyyy too many examples moved from sandboxes to even try to list here :) (@ msutkowski)
    • Match redux config for docusaurus webpack v5 (#1086 - @ msutkowski)
    • Some assorted content tweaks (@ markerikson)

    v1.6.0-beta.0...v1.6.0-rc.1

  • 1.6.0-rc.0 - 2021-06-03

    This release is broken due to a build misconfiguration - please see rc.1 instead:

    https://github.com/reduxjs/redux-toolkit/releases/tag/v1.6.0-rc.1

  • 1.6.0-beta.0 - 2021-05-22
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-alpha.2 - 2021-04-26

    This release fixes a bug with RTK Query cache invalidation, and exposes the useLazyQuerySubscription hook.

    Installation:

    npm i @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

yarn add @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

    Changelog

    Invalidation Bugfix

    We saw that RTK Query cache invalidation was actually broken in alpha.1. After investigation, it looks like TypeScript was outputting incorrect code for looping over a set.values() iterator. We've tweaked the logic to work around that.

    Please upgrade to this release ASAP, as invalidation is a key part of RTK Query's functionality.

    useLazyQuerySubscription

    The useLazyQuerySubscription hook was documented, but wasn't actually being included in the output. We've fixed that.

    Additional Build Tweaks

    We're still fiddling with the combination of ESBuild and TypeScript for our recently updated build chain, and have flipped a couple more switches in the process. Should be no user-visible difference.

    Changes

    • Expose useLazyQuerySubscription for endpoints ( #1017 - @ Shrugsy)
    • Fix bad transpilation of set iteration breaking invalidation (#1020 - @ markerikson)

    v1.6.0-alpha.1...v1.6.0-alpha.2

  • 1.6.0-alpha.1 - 2021-04-24
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-alpha.0 - 2021-04-04

    This initial pre-1.6 alpha release reworks our build tooling to enable upcoming changes, updates dependencies, adds new entity adapter CRUD methods, and tweaks async thunk options.

    We have several major improvements planned for later pre-1.6 alphas, including merging the "RTK Query" APIs back into RTK itself and making those available as subpackages.

    Changelog

    Build Tooling Updates

    We've replaced our existing TSDX build setup with a new custom setup based on ESBuild + TypeScript (thanks to @ hardfist for doing all the work on that!). In theory, we should have all of the same build artifacts we had before, targeting the same browser and ES spec levels. We did add a new set of "modern" build artifacts that target ES2017, with builds for bundlers and browwsers. However, we can't officially list those in package.json yet, as apparently defining an exports key can break Node and is considered a breaking change. We'll look at flipping that on in a future 2.0 release.

    Please let us know if you see any bugs that may be related to the build tooling and bundling changes!

    Dependency Updates

    We've updated Immer to 9.0.x. Also, we've updated Redux to the hot-off-the-presses 4.1.0-alpha.0, which shrinks bundle size by extracted error messages in production. Again, please report any problems you run into.

    New Entity Adapter Replace Methods

    createEntityAdapter already had methods to add, upsert, and update items. We've added setOne and setMany, which let you add or entirely replace existing items.

    Async Thunk Improvements

    createAsyncThunk promises now have a .unwrap() method that returns a promise for the actual result payload, or throws an error if the promise was rejected. This simplifies the use case of working with the thunk result in components.

    createAsyncThunk also now accepts an idGenerator option to let you swap out the default nanoid() ID generation utility for your own, such as uuid4.

    Other Updates

    We've done a bit of internal cleanup in a few functions to simplify and shorten implementations.

    configureStore now checks for accidentally returning undefined for a middleware array, or undefined entries in the array.

    The PreloadedState type should now work better with TS 4.3+.

    Changes

    • Bump Redux to 4.1.0-alpha.0 0169356
    • Update immer to v9.0.1 (#977) 087d4b6
    • Add idGenerator option to createAsyncThunk (#743) (#976) 309c4bd
    • Add simpler unwrapping of createAsyncThunk promises (#970) 8301370
    • Merge branch 'next' 247f9fe
    • Remove unnecessary condition (#846) 37d22c4
    • Add check for undefined middleware in configureStore (#959) 86f7eea
    • chore(build): move tsdx to esbuild (#957) cb0535d
    • Add setOne and setMany to entity adapter (#969) 795af40
    • Removed unnecessary sort in sorted_state_adapter.ts#merge() (#960) 4462647
    • Extract common utils from both adapter files (#952) 61ec24c
    • export AsyncThunkOptions (#950) 7db3e48
    • fix PreloadedState type for TS 4.3 (#949) 9abaec4

    v1.5.1...v1.6.0-alpha.0

  • 1.5.1 - 2021-03-26
    Read more
from @reduxjs/toolkit GitHub release notes

pull.title: [IMERC-293]: Display optimized route
pull.body:
[IMERC-293](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-293)
### ProjectMap [Modified]
- Added `userDefinedCoordinates` prop
- Added `optimizedCoordinates` prop
- Added `mode` prop to determine how the route should be rendered
- Updated stories to show the editable and display mode


### Marker [Modified]
- Added `draggable` prop to set whether a Marker should be draggable or not. (Draggable when editing, not draggable when displaying the optimized route)
- Made `onMarkerDrag` optional

### LinePath [Modified]
- Changed to functional component to be in line with all the other components on the project
- Used `React.memo()` to avoid not needed re-renders
- Added props to modify the color and type


### RoutePlanner [Modified]
- Changed how the points are stored. 
- Using `userDefinedPoints` and `optimizedPoints` to store the state of the route. 
- The `userDefinedCoordinates`  array is computed using React.useMemo() (triggered when `userDefinedPoints` changes)
- Added call to the backend to retrieve the optimized route and update the state

### RoutePlannerSidebar [Modified]
- Added prop to enable/disable the optimize button
- Moved condition to enable /disable the optimize button to `RoutePlanner`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30033816/125729533-f1548c19-c95d-4ee0-8050-b9b7f1638eb1.png)

comments.body: We could also type this as `Array<ProjectMapCoordinates>` for consistency

pull.title: [IMERC-293] Implement BE calls to Optimize Route
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Implements BE calls to store route, optimize and poll until optimization is successful.
- Improves generic API wrapper functions by adding the possibility to type their responses
- Adds reusable Modal component with backdrop
- Adds Spinner atom to indicate loading

## Context:
[[IMERC-293]](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-293)

## Screenshots/videos:
<details>
<summary>Click to expand</summary>

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8879212/125643903-40dc0e3d-ae7e-47fd-a233-de14b77c596e.mov
</details>

comments.body: Are these spacer divs? Use CSS for height instead?
Small nitpick: Are we linting CSS? I expect a newline between rules. Just preference, but curious if we are linting CSS at all.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,19 @@ +import { FC } from 'react'; +import styles from './index.module.css'; + +export const Spinner: FC = () => ( +
+
+
+
+

comments.body: Each div represents one "line" of the spinner. They then get targeted individually within the CSS file. I got the spinner from here: https://loading.io/css/
CSS files are getting formatted by Prettier but we have no styling linter. I'll add the newlines manually, I also prefer having it that way.
Could there be a case where `points` is still `null` when rendering this component? maybe we can say `points?.length < 2` just to be safe? (not needed if you think this is not a real use case)
`points` gets initialized as an array with 1 point (the start point) and then gets passed down to the sidebar. I believe there's no scenario where this could be null.
I think we want to enable this cancel button and attach an API call to `/projects/{projectId}/routes/{routeId}/optimizations/{id}/cancel` to cancel the request.
If an error occurs, we probably want to `setIsRouteBeingOptimized(false);` to hide the modal.

pull.title: [IMERC-285]: Route planner template
pull.body:
[Story 285](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-285)

- Add/update coords via Start Point coordinate panel
- Add/update coords via End Point coordinate panel
- Drag marker on map and it updates coords in respective coordinate panel

![route-planner](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/125555659-73763e32-21f0-489f-b047-f717056aa037.gif)


**Note:** the main folders to review are `src/molecules/ProjectMap` and `src/templates/RoutePlanner`. The other file changes are mainly padding that was added or removed in order to show the map full screen without an overflow.

comments.body:
Name here should be kept as required, as it's needed for the backend call.
Following Scott's video, points should automatically have a name when added (eg: "Start Point", "End Point", "Point 2"...) so I don't think there's a valid scenario where a Point will have no name.
I believe this is not needed anymore since we are using the `loggedInUser` to fetch the project
Move this 1 line below
I would say we can go and remove the comment as this is just a warning and won't prevent the changes from being pushed.
If we don't need the setter function we can remove it from the array, and remove the comment above. Also, do we need this as state or can it be just a const?
I don't have that much experience with classes but I think we can remove the underscore and remove the comment at the top of the file?
We can go with the more strict typing by using Array<[number, number]> as we use on the rest of the components
We can also use here the more strict typing

+/* eslint-disable react/no-array-index-key */
comments.body: Rule is set as a warning, so it won't prevent pushing to a branch. My recommendation is to only disable the linter on specific errors that don't make sense for a particular case
Well the type will be updated. There are supposed to be a few different states to the marker. So that's why it's here for now.

pull.title: [IMERC-283] Create left navigation
pull.body:
[IMERC-283](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-283)

### Sidebar [New]

- Control initial open/close state with `isOpen` prop
- Toggles open/close when arrow button is clicked
- +stories, +tests

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30033816/124982212-114ddc00-dffc-11eb-936e-25d00a71abac.mov

pull.title: [IMERC-292]: Integrate DeckGL POC map
pull.body:
[Story 292](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-292)

This PR covers the basic requirements: 

- DeckGL map instance in the frontend of the application
- Display 1 type (arbitrary) of basemap (static image layer)
- Bare minimum map controls: pan + zoom
- Allows origin and destination points to be dropped directly on map with straight line drawn between them

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/125021337-46bfed00-e02f-11eb-9dfd-a28ff51424d2.mp4

However, the way in which the map is currently set up is not entirely finished, therefore there aren't any tests.

comments.body: can we have this in as an environment variable?
@johannmorales just turned that into an environment variable. 👍

- Adding +1 and removed phone formatting to avoid test failures due to the phone number validation bug at https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-265

pull.title: [IMERC-279]: Create GeoPointDetails molecule
pull.body:
### Details [New]
- Displays component passed on `title` prop
- Displays component passed on `content` prop when opened
- Opens/closes according to `isOpen` prop
- Has open/close transition
- +stories, +tests

### EditableElement [New _kinda_]
- Abstracted logic from `EditableTitle` so it is not tied to a `Title` atom
- Element component passed on `element` prop

### EditableTitle [Modified]
- Removed most component logic
- Returns a modified `EditableElement` with  `Title` as `element`


### Paragraph [Modified]
- Added new color (cyan-700)

### GeoPointDetails [New]
- Uses `Details` and `EditableElement` with `Paragraph`
- Needs `isOpen`, `isEditing`, `toggleOpen` and `toggleEditing` props. Created hook `useGeoPointDetails` that returns  those props.
- +stories, +tests

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+import React, { FC, ReactNode, useMemo, useRef } from 'react';
comments.body: Minor, but since React 17, importing React is not necessary anymore
I would say it feels more natural to use children instead of passing down components as a prop, especially as this component will be used as a wrapper
For consistency we should import useEffect and use it directly
Same as above, I would suggest using children. Although I think this might make more sense, at least for me children feels more natural
Setting a prop as true is redundant, setting it as `showEditIcon` is the recommended way. The new linting changes will also mark this as an error
Should we make use of default values here? We could initialize `name = ''` on line 43 as an empty string, and then on this line just refer to `name`. Thoughts?
Seeing as this is a boolean it probably makes more sense having this as `[isOpen, setIsOpen]`, instead of just `open` which seems to be an action
As commented above, `isOpen={true}` is redundant, using just `isOpen` is preferred
Refer to comment above about boolean props and please check repeated instances on this same file

I don't think using `children` here would make sense since this component is not a wrapper and `element` won't even be rendered at all sometimes. 

Do you think it is necessary to use `children` in this case?
Yeah, agreed that for this case using children might not make the most sense.

I need to know if it is undefined in order to decide whether the user is creating a new point or editing an existing one. I could change the validation rule to `isNew = name === ''` but it feels like it would break if for any reason a point has an empty name. What do you think works best in this scenario?

`isNew` will also be `true` if `name` is `''` as it's a falsy value, so `!''= true`

If we want to differentiate between an empty name and no name, then we should be more strict in the check, maybe setting `name` to be `null` as default, and doing `const isNew = name === null` 

By the way, should we allow the user to have a point with no name?

You are right, I will update the condition to be `const isNew = name === null` and add a default value.

> By the way, should we allow the user to have a point with no name?

No, the input wont let you submit empty values, just mentioning that if for any reason we get corrupted data from the backend

pull.title: ESLint config changes
pull.body:
## Changes:
- Add `eslint-plugin-prettier` and extend the recommended configuration. This integrates ESLint and Prettier which means formatting errors will be highlighted in red, giving a clearer idea of existing issues. Running `npm run lint` will also fix formatting issues.
- Extend the default config (`airbnb-typescript`) instead of the base one. The default includes linting rules for React and React hooks which makes sense to use as this is a React application.
- Various fixes based on the new added rules.
- Most accesibility related rules have been set to warn only instead of error. Ideally we would fix these and then set the rules back to error but I would consider this not to be a priority right now, so I set them to warn only as to not block the PR.

## Context:
We're currently not leveraging and taking advantage of the full power of ESLint. Setting these new rules, especially the React related ones, will help us ensure that the application behaves as expected.

Most of these changes are based on personal experience so I consider them to be positive for the development flow, but let's have an open discussion about it.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
 #!/bin/sh
 . "$(dirname "$0")/_/husky.sh"
 
-npm run format && npm run lint
+npm run lint
comments.body:
what do you think on having two different npm commands on the `package.json`, `npm run lint` and `npm run lint:fix`? 

I think unless the developer actually looks at the package file it's not clear that the `lint` command it's actually going to run with the `fix` flag.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
 #!/bin/sh
 . "$(dirname "$0")/_/husky.sh"
 
-npm run format && npm run lint
+npm run lint
comments.body: Agreed! I've added a separate script with the fix flag for both linting and formatting.

pull.title: [Snyk] Upgrade @reduxjs/toolkit from 1.5.1 to 1.6.0
pull.body:
Snyk has created this PR to upgrade @reduxjs/toolkit from 1.5.1 to 1.6.0.

![merge advice](https://app.snyk.io/badges/merge-advice/?package_manager=npm&package_name=@reduxjs/toolkit&from_version=1.5.1&to_version=1.6.0&pr_id=052c74e4-559a-4d13-8573-2099ccb087a2&visibility=true&has_feature_flag=false) :sparkles: Snyk has automatically assigned this pull request, [set who gets assigned](https://app.snyk.io/org/imercatus/project/0e68cc6f-8544-4ce5-a74b-b04fc90d9ba2/settings/integration?utm_source=github&utm_medium=upgrade-pr/settings/integration). :information_source: Keep your dependencies up-to-date. This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
- The recommended version is **7 versions** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **22 days ago**, on 2021-06-07.
Release notes
Package name: @reduxjs/toolkit
  • 1.6.0 - 2021-06-07
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-rc.1 - 2021-06-03

    This release candidate finalizes the upcoming RTK Query APIs. It adds new options to createAsyncThunk for adding meta fields to thunk-dispatched actions, updates the createApi lifecycle handlers to pass through those meta fields, and removes fields that were deprecated during the alpha process. We've also fleshed out the RTKQ preview docs with significant new content.

    This should be the final preview before the RTK 1.6 final release, barring any unforeseen last-minute bugs. (Note: This is the same content as rc.0, but we found a bug in our build process that had wrong output in that release. Hopefully no more issues!)

    The preview docs are located at https://deploy-preview-1016--redux-starter-kit-docs.netlify.app .

    Installation:

    npm i @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

yarn add @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

    Changelog

    Async Thunk meta Support

    createAsyncThunk automatically generates action creators and action types, and then automatically dispatches those actions during execution. This simplifies the process of creating and using thunks, but like all abstractions, also limits flexibility.

    One limitation has been that there was no way to customize the meta field to the actions generated by createAsyncThunk, and some users needed to add additional metadata to actions for use by other middleware.

    We've updated createAsyncThunk to allow adding additional contents to meta. The approach varies based on the action type:

    • pending: there is a new getPendingMeta({arg, requestId}) callback that can be passed as part of the createAsyncThunk options object. This is necessary because the pending action is dispatched before the payload creator is even called.
    • fulfilled: there is a new fulfillWithMeta utility in the payload creator's thunkApi object, which can be used instead of returning the payload directly: return fulfillWithMeta(actualPayload, meta)
    • rejected: the existing rejectWithValue utility now also accepts a meta argument: return rejectWithValue(failedPayload, meta)

    API Lifecycle meta Support

    The createApi cache lifecycle callbacks like onCacheEntryAdded now make the meta field available as part of the promise result, such as cacheDataLoaded.

    Code Cleanup and Types Tweaks

    The fields such as onStart and onSuccess that were deprecated in earlier alphas have been removed.

    The now-unused ApiWithInjectedEndpoints type was removed.

    Various APIs that accept arrays were updated to mark those array parameters as readonly, to help indicate that they shouldn't be mutated, and to ensure that arrays marked as const can be accepted.

    The ApiModules type was modified to prevent a inferred type of this node exceeds the maximum length the compiler will serialize TS error.

    Docs Updates

    We've updated to Docusaurus 2.0-beta.0, which includes Webpack 5. No visible change for you, but faster CI builds for us thanks to build artifact caching! (Our docs builds dropped from around 7 minutes each build down to around 25 seconds, thanks to only changed files being rebuilt.)

    We've also completed filling out the RTK Query API docs.

    Changes

    Code

    • Remove upcoming alpha.3 deprecations (#1052 - @ phryneas)
    • createAsyncThunk: support for meta (#1083 - @ phryneas)
    • Add baseQueryMeta to thunks, meta to lifecycle results (#1083 - @ phryneas)
    • Remove ApiWithInjectedEndpoints references (#1112 - @ msutkowski)
    • Add readonly to array-type function params (#1113 - @ phryneas)
    • remove Id to force lazy evaluation of API type (#1116 - @ phryneas)

    Docs

    • Wayyyy too many docs PRs to even try to list here :) (@ Shrugsy)
    • Wayyyy too many examples moved from sandboxes to even try to list here :) (@ msutkowski)
    • Match redux config for docusaurus webpack v5 (#1086 - @ msutkowski)
    • Some assorted content tweaks (@ markerikson)

    v1.6.0-beta.0...v1.6.0-rc.1

  • 1.6.0-rc.0 - 2021-06-03

    This release is broken due to a build misconfiguration - please see rc.1 instead:

    https://github.com/reduxjs/redux-toolkit/releases/tag/v1.6.0-rc.1

  • 1.6.0-beta.0 - 2021-05-22
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-alpha.2 - 2021-04-26

    This release fixes a bug with RTK Query cache invalidation, and exposes the useLazyQuerySubscription hook.

    Installation:

    npm i @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

yarn add @ reduxjs/toolkit@next

    Changelog

    Invalidation Bugfix

    We saw that RTK Query cache invalidation was actually broken in alpha.1. After investigation, it looks like TypeScript was outputting incorrect code for looping over a set.values() iterator. We've tweaked the logic to work around that.

    Please upgrade to this release ASAP, as invalidation is a key part of RTK Query's functionality.

    useLazyQuerySubscription

    The useLazyQuerySubscription hook was documented, but wasn't actually being included in the output. We've fixed that.

    Additional Build Tweaks

    We're still fiddling with the combination of ESBuild and TypeScript for our recently updated build chain, and have flipped a couple more switches in the process. Should be no user-visible difference.

    Changes

    • Expose useLazyQuerySubscription for endpoints ( #1017 - @ Shrugsy)
    • Fix bad transpilation of set iteration breaking invalidation (#1020 - @ markerikson)

    v1.6.0-alpha.1...v1.6.0-alpha.2

  • 1.6.0-alpha.1 - 2021-04-24
    Read more
  • 1.6.0-alpha.0 - 2021-04-04

    This initial pre-1.6 alpha release reworks our build tooling to enable upcoming changes, updates dependencies, adds new entity adapter CRUD methods, and tweaks async thunk options.

    We have several major improvements planned for later pre-1.6 alphas, including merging the "RTK Query" APIs back into RTK itself and making those available as subpackages.

    Changelog

    Build Tooling Updates

    We've replaced our existing TSDX build setup with a new custom setup based on ESBuild + TypeScript (thanks to @ hardfist for doing all the work on that!). In theory, we should have all of the same build artifacts we had before, targeting the same browser and ES spec levels. We did add a new set of "modern" build artifacts that target ES2017, with builds for bundlers and browwsers. However, we can't officially list those in package.json yet, as apparently defining an exports key can break Node and is considered a breaking change. We'll look at flipping that on in a future 2.0 release.

    Please let us know if you see any bugs that may be related to the build tooling and bundling changes!

    Dependency Updates

    We've updated Immer to 9.0.x. Also, we've updated Redux to the hot-off-the-presses 4.1.0-alpha.0, which shrinks bundle size by extracted error messages in production. Again, please report any problems you run into.

    New Entity Adapter Replace Methods

    createEntityAdapter already had methods to add, upsert, and update items. We've added setOne and setMany, which let you add or entirely replace existing items.

    Async Thunk Improvements

    createAsyncThunk promises now have a .unwrap() method that returns a promise for the actual result payload, or throws an error if the promise was rejected. This simplifies the use case of working with the thunk result in components.

    createAsyncThunk also now accepts an idGenerator option to let you swap out the default nanoid() ID generation utility for your own, such as uuid4.

    Other Updates

    We've done a bit of internal cleanup in a few functions to simplify and shorten implementations.

    configureStore now checks for accidentally returning undefined for a middleware array, or undefined entries in the array.

    The PreloadedState type should now work better with TS 4.3+.

    Changes

    • Bump Redux to 4.1.0-alpha.0 0169356
    • Update immer to v9.0.1 (#977) 087d4b6
    • Add idGenerator option to createAsyncThunk (#743) (#976) 309c4bd
    • Add simpler unwrapping of createAsyncThunk promises (#970) 8301370
    • Merge branch 'next' 247f9fe
    • Remove unnecessary condition (#846) 37d22c4
    • Add check for undefined middleware in configureStore (#959) 86f7eea
    • chore(build): move tsdx to esbuild (#957) cb0535d
    • Add setOne and setMany to entity adapter (#969) 795af40
    • Removed unnecessary sort in sorted_state_adapter.ts#merge() (#960) 4462647
    • Extract common utils from both adapter files (#952) 61ec24c
    • export AsyncThunkOptions (#950) 7db3e48
    • fix PreloadedState type for TS 4.3 (#949) 9abaec4

    v1.5.1...v1.6.0-alpha.0

  • 1.5.1 - 2021-03-26
    Read more

pull.title: [IMERC-236]: create ProjectPlannerSteps molecule
pull.body:
[Story 236](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-236)

- Creates the **`<ProjectsStepper />`** molecule (+ tests) and its' props are: 
  - _`dataTestId?: string`_
  - _`steps: {dataTestId?: string; text: string; key: any;}[]`_ 
  - _`handleStepClick: (stepIndex: number) => void`_
  - _`currActiveStep: number`_
- Extends the **`<Paragraph />`** atom with prop:
  -  _`weight?: 'light' | 'normal' | 'medium' | 'semibold' | 'bold'`_
- Extends TW config: 
  - adds plugin to style border color for `top`, `left`, `right`, and `bottom` (ex: `border-l-cyan-700`)
  - updates `cyan-700` color with most current color
  - extends default `borderWidth`
- Update stories that are using `<Link />` with `<MemoryRouter />` 


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/123504779-0d8b8400-d610-11eb-908c-09d65743b25b.mp4

comments.body: `activeStep` is not being used

I don't think one step should be aware of the length of the array of steps nor which index it has. 

Maybe change logic to accept something like `type: 'default' | 'first' | 'last'` and refactor `ProjectStepper` so he is the one that defines which type of `Step` should be rendered
Consider passing the click event as a parameter. Disregard if you have already made sure that we wont need it (e.g. for stopping event propagation)

The logic to create the data-testid could be split so `Step` doesn't need to know which index it has.

ProjectStepper:
```
<Step dataTestId={`${dataTestId}--project-step-${index}} .../>
```

Step:
```
<li data-testid={`${dataTestId}--link`}> 
...
<Paragraph  dataTestId={`${dataTestId}--text`}> 
```
We shouldn't use the item index as a key. Please add a `key` property to `ProjectStep` and use that instead.
is there a reason on needed a ternary here instead of just using `condition && jsx` if we don't care about the false scenario?
Same comment as with `leftHiddenEl`

pull.title: [IMERC-229]: Create (initial) Projects page
pull.body:
[**Story 229**
](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-229)


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/124029474-08c92600-d9aa-11eb-8964-d5f3ec294753.mp4



- Adds API call to soft delete (archive) a project
- Adds API call to fetch projects
  - currently, a function aptly named `addTemporaryMissingKeysFromBackEnd()` is being called inside of the `fetchProjects()`  to add dummy data for keys that are not present on the project model yet  
- Replaces previous props of`<Projects />` with **`loggedInUser`** and **`dataTestId`**
- Creates **`<ProjectCardList />`** molecule with following props: 
  - `dataTestId?: string;`
  - `projects: ProjectEntity[];`
  - `onArchiveProjectClick: (projectId: any) => void;`
  - `onDuplicateProjectClick: (projectId: any) => void;`
  - `onProjectClick: (projectId: any) => void;`
  - `ownerName: string;`
- Adds tests + storybook for `<ProjectCardList />` molecule
- Adds `react-toastify` message to screen after project has been archived

comments.body: Should this be a component?
Yeah, it'd read better as it's own component. I'll change that.

Should the  archive action be dangerous and separated by a divider as it is on the `UserProfile` actions?

Yeah, I think that makes a lot of sense! Standardizing in a component (or some kind of hook) would be the best approach. Johann will be taking point on this @mfcallahan.

@@ -0,0 +1,32 @@
+import { z } from 'zod';
+
+export const projectEntitySchema = z.object({
+  id: z.number().optional(),

comments.body: Yeah, I think you're right that it'd be easier to just reference the `userEntitySchema` like `users: z.array(userEntitySchema).optional()`. However, when hitting the`/projects/mine` endpoint, it seems like some of the properties can be `null` for the users array (like `invitationToken`), but in the `userEntitySchema` it's not? Similarly, properties like `createdAt` and `updatedAt` are not necessarily `Date` types from backend but rather `string` types? So there's some discrepancy (or I may be missing something). @alkema @t3hpr1m3 @johannmorales

@johannmorales after I archive a project, what do you think about displaying a toast message that says something to the effect of "Project X has been archived"? Currently, it just vanishes after you click the archive button, so it's a bit abrupt.

Sounds good, the user should be notified that his action has been processed successfully. 

I would like to reuse that toast (a dangerous variant of it) for the generic error handling function included on [New Project PR](https://github.com/iMercatus/imercata-web/pull/172) . What do you think about that?

Yeah, I think that sounds great! `react-toastify` is already included in the list of our dependencies, so go ahead and use it.

pull.title: [NO-TICKET]: Refactor EditAdminRoleUsers
pull.body:
**NOTE: THIS IS ESSENTIALLY A REFACTOR OF [PR 153](https://github.com/iMercatus/imercata-web/pull/153)**
- Refactored `<EditAdminRoleUsers />` into a simple table that accepts two props: **_`usersAddedToRole`_** and **_`onDeleteUser`_**.
- Refactored the header and slideover components that were originally sub components of `<EditAdminRoleUsers />` into their own molecules: **`<EditAdminRoleUsersActions />`** and **`<EditAdminRoleUsersSlideOver />`**
  - added new prop **_`adminRoleId`_** to `<EditAdminRoleUsersActions />`
  - changed _`onSubmit`_, _`onAddNewUserSubmit`_ and _`users`_ of `<EditAdminRoleUsersActions />` and `<EditAdminRoleUsersSlideOver />` to clearer prop names: **_`onAddNewUsersToRoleSubmit`_**, **_`onInviteNewUserToRoleSubmit`_**, and **_`usersNotAddedToRole`_**
- Created **`<EditAdminRoleTemplate />`** (watch demo below) which is comprised of both the `<EditAdminRolePermissions />` and `<EditAdminRoleUsers />` 
  - **`<EditAdminRoleTemplate />`** accepts following props (which are essentially just the individual props for `<EditAdminRolePermissions />` and `<EditAdminRoleUsers />`): _**`availableFeatures`**_, _**`avatar`**_, _**`users`**_, _**`adminRoleId`**_, _**`roleName`**_, _**`onDeleteUser`**_, _**`onSearchInputChange`**_, _**`onInviteNewUserToRoleSubmit`**_, _**`onAddNewUsersToRoleSubmit`**_ 
- Divvied specs of `EditAdminRoleUsers.spec.tsx` into own spec files: _**`EditAdminRoleUsersActions.spec.tsx`**_ and  _**`EditAdminRoleUsersSlideOver.spec.tsx`**_ 


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/123019649-bb373280-d385-11eb-8516-5e4593f8d379.mp4
