- The recommended version is **1 version** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **21 days ago**, on 2021-05-13.
Release notes
Package name: @hookform/resolvers
  • 2.5.0 - 2021-05-13

    2.5.0 (2021-05-13)

    Features

    • computed-types resolver (#162) (85e5e7d)
    import React from 'react';
import { useForm } from 'react-hook-form';
import { computedTypesResolver } from '@ hookform/resolvers/computed-types';
import Schema, { number, string } from 'computed-types';

const schema = Schema({
  username: string.min(1).error('username field is required'),
  password: string.min(1).error('password field is required'),
  password: number,
});

const App = () => {
  const {
    register,
    handleSubmit,
    formState: { errors },
  } = useForm({
    resolver: computedTypesResolver(schema),
  });

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit((d) => console.log(d))}>
      <input {...register('name')} />
      {errors.name?.message && <p>{errors.name?.message}</p>}
      <input type="number" {...register('age', { valueAsNumber: true })} />
      {errors.age?.message && <p>{errors.age?.message}</p>}
      <input type="submit" />
    </form>
  );
};

export default App;
  • 2.4.0 - 2021-04-17

    2.4.0 (2021-04-17)

    Features

    • nope resolver (#158) (c8b961b)
    import React from 'react';
import { useForm } from 'react-hook-form';
import { nopeResolver } from '@ hookform/resolvers/nope';
import Nope from 'nope-validator';

const schema = Nope.object().shape({
  name: Nope.string().required(),
  age: Nope.number().required(),
});

const App = () => {
  const { register, handleSubmit } = useForm({
    resolver: nopeResolver(schema),
  });

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit((d) => console.log(d))}>
      <input name="name" ref={register} />
      <input name="age" type="number" ref={register} />
      <input type="submit" />
    </form>
  );
};

export default App;

pull.title: [IMERC-192] - Create radio buttom atom
pull.body:
Includes: 
- RadioButton atom
- RadioButton tests
- RadioButton Storybook

RadioButton features:
- Preselect value
- Trigger function on change
- Display simple label (text)
- Display complex label (JSX.Element)

comments.body:
the way you are developing this makes this a checkbox and not a radio button... I mean, radio button groups, for example, should not allow more than one item to be picked. I don't see you handling that here. Also, TailwindUI and Headless UI already have components that would help:

- https://tailwindui.com/components/application-ui/forms/radio-groups
- https://headlessui.dev/react/radio-group
I would add another expect before the click event `expect(element).not.toBeChecked()` since the goal of the test is to verify it changes the check value when clicked
added the validation on new commit
We are actually focusing more on using `data-testid` for this kind of tests. Just like they mention here: https://docs.cypress.io/guides/references/best-practices#Selecting-Elements

pull.title: [IMERC-166]: Create Navbar organism
pull.body: https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/119741340-5c3fd580-be3a-11eb-8133-26c1af06a179.mp4

comments.body: I tried `.toBeVisible()` here but it said that it wasn't visible in the document, which is weird because the other elements did work when I used this. So I'm not sure where it's going wrong to not resize the component.
This is done to get jest to allow us to use `matchMedia`.
This is done because `innerWidth` is a read only property.
This whole function is odd, but I saw that I was repeating myself with resizing and mounting the component with the data properties.

comments.body: Hey, @zackcarlson. I'm approving and merging this PR, but wanted to comment that this might not be a very good approach. I mean, for this very small component, all good, but for something a little bit more complex, just checking how many children the component has can hide some issue. For example, if someone makes a mistake and switches what get rendered (i.e., makes it render `Badge` instead of `BellIcon`), this test would still pass.

comments.body:
[on TailwindUI, I can scroll horizontally](https://tailwindui.com/components/application-ui/lists/tables)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15347252/119067221-f70e5f00-b9b7-11eb-82a7-1efcb549cdee.png)

on this component, I can't, (or at least in the story I can't).

If you look on TailwindUI example code, you will see three levels of divs on top of the one you copied (the one with this `overflow-hidden` class), would they be the missing key to fix this?
why did you need the `leading-4`? Asking because I didn't see on TailwindUI and when I removed couldn't see any visible diff.
The Figma design uses that class to define the line height
Fixed on new commit, added 2 divs that wrap the table because just removing the `overflow-hidden` class breaks the table border

pull.title: [IMERC 179]: Create SlideOver
pull.body:
This PR:

- creates the `<SlideOver />` component (_and its Storybook_)
- extends the `<Title />` component (_and its Storybook_) with additional levels and colors and extends `<Paragraph />` component with colors.
  - originally I created the `<SlideOver />` with `<Title />` and `<Paragraph />` components so that's why these changes are here. regardless, these props will be useful in the future as we will need them


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/118907364-3cf1f700-b8d4-11eb-8e60-91c69078a6e5.mp4

comments.body:
I don't think we need either the `tertiary` button (this comment is related to the message I sent to you over slack) and I don't think we need the `quaternary` button.

Regarding the `quaternary` button, I feel like adding logic (even if it is just a one liner) to the button for a close icon on a modal is mixing up stuff. What I mean is, let's use buttons for forms, and lets implement this X icon inside the modal itself. That is, the SlideOver should be importing the button.
I think you can remove from here (based on my previous comment).
if you agree with my previous comment, you will end up reverting all changes to this file

that's how they handle screen readers? gosh, that's... strange. I would expect an `aria-` attribute or similar... could you double check this? I think we might not even need this. It should probably be part of the `<button>` below as an `aria` attribute. Can you double check?
just reinforcing, I would use the atom here, but a native `<button>` instead to avoid adding stuff to the atom codebase.
I do understand the white color (for the slider headers) but what about the other two? Where are they used? Sorry for so many questions, but good code is no code.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -46,7 +46,7 @@ export const RegistrationBusinessType = forwardRef< />
- +
comments.body:
Why 3? Does it say that on the Figma file? It looks like a 2 to me (based on the context). If you made this change based on the `3xl`, `2xl`, `xl` scale I think you don't need to go down that path. I mean, nothing out there says that `3xl` is `h1` and that, for that, `h2` would be one down `2xl`.

If we end up moving this title back to `level="2"` I would even undo the changes you made to the title component.
Yeah, I agree with this. I'll revert the Button and just use a native button for the close icon.
Yeah, that's how the Tailwind docs wrote it, but I can modify it to use an `aria-` instead.
You're right, I'll remove the gray-800 and cyan colors; they should be applied to a separate `` component. I had conflated the `` with text. (_uses `gray-800` and `gray-500`_)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -46,7 +46,7 @@ export const RegistrationBusinessType = forwardRef< />
- +
comments.body: Yeah, I didn't want to mess with your structure of that file so that's why I just added a third component ``. But to avoid any code repetition I'll change the `` to just render a single HTML element instead. And the reasoning behind adding a third level is: the `<Title />` component will be used in the `InviteUsersSlideOver`, and the font size of that title is `24px` (`1.5rem`), which is `text-2xl` in Tailwind. So because the title had `xl` (level 2) and `3xl` (level 1), I changed the `xl` to a level 1 and made the `2xl` a level 2, which then created 3 levels altogether (_sorry if that sounds confusing_). <img width="758" alt="Screen Shot 2021-05-19 at 2 58 06 PM" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/118890638-e4aafd00-b8b3-11eb-98d2-1ff5807ba81a.png">
Yeah, I agree.

I'm curious about the best approach to pass different styles to the ``? If I import the close button into the `` component, then I suppose the `` should accept an optional property for styling the close button. It seems the first image is also a slide over and it doesn't have a close button.
I'll also remove the weight from this component. That should be applied to the `<Text />` component.

I wouldn't worry about making this a configurable option. In fact, I have the impression we won't even use the SlideOver component on the route planner feature. I mean, there is a component there that does look like a SlideOver, but it behaves differently and it is presented differently.

For example, on the component that gets rendered on the route planner, clicking outside the slide over, won't close it. Also, there is no back shadow on it. So I wouldn't reuse it. I would create a brand new one, from scratch when we get there. More components, yes, but makes every single piece easier to reason about.

Well, they probably have more experience than I, so they are probably right and I'm wrong? Anyway, a small research might help. Or, if a small research does not solve the question of what would be better, let's go their way (again, they probably have more experience than I on that topic)

According to [this article](https://www.sarasoueidan.com/blog/accessible-icon-buttons/), I can attach an aria-label to the xicon itself and remove the span. However, the way that the Tailwind docs show it is also valid. I'll just attach the aria-label onto the xicon. It's simpler since the button doesn't have any text content inside of it.

comments.body: I think we will never have a feature that shows if a user is connected or not, so I would either remove the circle completely or use it as an indicator of whether the user is `active`, `pending`, or `locked`.

pull.title: [IMERC-92]: Create Email Table View (Invite Users)
pull.body:
This PR: 

- Creates an editable table view component `<EditParsedContent />`
- Creates a reusable `<DropDown />` component (used by `<EditParsedContent />` and `<User />`)
- Extends the `<Input />` component to: 
  - optionally pass a _label_, which will show the label and its `transform` animation when provided
  - optionally pass  a _size_ prop to determine a `large` or `small` height for the input
  - attach the current error handling to the `onChange` event 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/117083634-0031d780-acfa-11eb-9e4c-60f972db7dc6.mp4

comments.body: The `useEffect` essentially prevents showing errors for an empty input on mount. Primarily this function is for the case when a user hasn't interacted with the input, yet. This is an inelegant way to do this check. Instead, it may be better to pass a property `validateOnMount` or something, to determine when we want to first run the validation.

It's better to show the state of the errors as the user types so that way they know if they've typed a valid input or not in real time. As opposed to how it is currently where they have to click out of the input to see if it's correct or not.
The label and its `transform` animation will show only if a label is passed to the component. This API allows a little more flexibility in using this input.

comments.body:
If, for whatever reason, someone opens the `/users?inviteModalStep=editParsed` path (which we intentionally allowed them to do), they will see an empty modal with no inputs available and no way to add new users apart from going to the previous screen, adding them, then clicking next.

So, IMO, we will have to either always include an extra empty row that they can fill (and an empty row when there is nothing on the screen) or we don't allow them to see this path without going through the previous one first.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15347252/117141045-7713b280-ad84-11eb-847d-b364d7c7e31f.png)

As part of an experiment, I removed `@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons` and the diff was only that on the screenshot below. So I wonder if, by installing it, NPM decided to update the other deps, or if you ran some other command. But it is a good practice to check at least the number of lines being changed on `package-lock.json` to see if you find anything out of the ordinary.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15347252/117142475-200edd00-ad86-11eb-9f90-ceee55ffbefe.png)

On the first image, on the dev tools, you can see that below the `<header>` I have only `<table>` (well, inside a single `<div>` but that belongs to the parent component).

I decided to replace the `UserCard` with this table because when scrolling horizontally the headers need to align with the current data cell we're looking at. Also, with this table, I'm able to click open the drop-down menu without it being hidden or clipped out of view. 

There's probably a simpler way to achieve this but this is the best I could do.
The `relative` position on the parent allows for the absolute `ul` child element to sit right below the parent.

You'll notice that the table doesn't span the entire length of the screen. I didn't know how to get this to work. I tried combining it with `flex` but that ended up messing with the `overflow`. So, I'm not entirely sure how to marry the two at the moment.

@brunokrebs The purpose of making this component a table was **1)** the Figma design is a table and **2)** the headers need to align with their appropriate data cells when scrolling and resizing the viewport. The current merged version does not account for these scenarios.

pull.title: [IMERC-91] code review
pull.body:
Around `30kb` saved here ([check comments on the original PR](https://github.com/iMercatus/imercata-web/pull/45/files#r624553386)).

By the way, @zackcarlson, we need to decide if we want to show and highlight duplicates or if we want to remove any duplicates (current behaviour). I guess the current behaviour is fine, but let's talk with Amman.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,23 +1,16 @@
+import uniq from 'lodash/uniq';
comments.body:
We need to import like that instead of:

```ts
import { uniq } from 'lodash';
```

Because we need to avoid importing the whole `lodash` library into the final bundle. Another alternative would be configuring `babel-plugin-lodash`: https://lodash.com/per-method-packages
with lines 8, 9 and 10, we cover emails separated by `,`, `;` and new lines (`\n`).

`as something` is something you shouldn't be using that much. The `as` keyword will make TypeScript "blindly" believe that the thing you are casting is really what you are saying, even if it is not.

This would be better:

```ts
let uniqueEmails: string[] = [];
```

pull.title: [IMERC-91] Create Email Parser Input
pull.body:
This PR:

- Uses regex in helper function `parseAndRemoveDuplicateEmails`
- Creates the `<InviteUsersModal />`, which shows different modal content based on current query params
  - **For example:** `/users/?inviteModalStep=parseContent` shows the CSV email parser input whereas the `/users/?inviteModalStep=editParsed` shows the list of parsed emails
- Extends the base `<Modal />` component with the property `closeModalOnOutsideClick` to give the developer more control 

_Note: in the video below, the given CSV string contains 5 emails with 2 duplicates. The final modal screen shows only 3 emails, but this is because duplicates have been removed._

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/116759551-74e9d680-a9c7-11eb-8dd9-4ba653561262.mp4

comments.body:
Let's not validate emails here or, even more important, let's not silently remove invalid emails from the list of users to be invited. We should show to them, in a visual way, that an email address is invalid, and we can do that on the next task (by adding a red outline to the input with the invalid email).

The problem is, imagine someone is copying 50 emails from a spreadsheet and one of the email address there is `zackgmail.com` (without the `@` symbol). With the current implementation, we would let users move to the next screen with 49 emails, but `zackgmail.com` would not be there.

Not a big deal since we are just inviting users here, but it is an important mindset for other features in the future. If someone is inputting some invalid values, let's tell them.
Even though the screens read "Add new user" I would call these elements `InviteUsersModal`, it reflects way better what we have here.

`newUser` looks to me like the name of a variable that holds a new user, not a variable that holds the state of the UI to show/hide a modal. Wouldn't something like `inviteModal` be better? Or `inviteModalStep`...
do you need to export lines 3 and 4? Aren't they used only inside `AddNewUserModal`?

pull.title: [IMERC-97] Proxy between Next.js and Nest.js
pull.body:
As we talked on the deployment model call, we will be using Next.js API capability to proxy requests to our REST API. This will help us with security (by not exposing access tokens, just cookies on browsers) and will leave the REST API, for the moment, available only for those with access to the private subnet on our AWS VPC.

Notes:
- With this PR, access tokens will be automatically attached (if available, of course) to each request.
- Any request that needs to be sent to the REST API, needs to be prefixed with `/api/v1`. So, if the endpoint you want is `/secured` on the REST API, here it will be `/api/v1/secured`.
- If you are sending a request from the a SSR endpoint to the REST API, you need a full path like `${process.env.NEXTJS_PUBLIC_URL}/api/v1/users/auth0-profile`
- If you are sending a request from the browser, then `/api/v1/users/auth0-profile` will suffice.
- `REST_API_PRIVATE_URL` will only be used by the middleware/proxy itself and shouldn't be used elsewhere

pull.title: [IMERC-90] Create Modal
pull.body:
This PR:

- Creates a generic `<Modal />` 
- Creates a hook `useModal` to open, close, and show modal
- Adds `<Modal />` to Storybook
- Adds Jest unit tests for  `<Modal />`
- Fixes `<UserCard/>` alignment


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30512292/116596876-c87df680-a8d9-11eb-87ba-0b0b79143216.mp4

comments.body: I would use something like `isModalVisible` to make it easier to understand that this is a boolean. Otherwise, `showModal` and `openModal` both look like would do the same action.
do you need that? minor, almost useless, comment, but I'm wondering if I'm missing something
I feel like this whole `handleCloseClick` thing is not needed and that you can pass `onClose` directly inside `onClick={onClose}`. The question is, is `e.preventDefault();` useful?
Never seen a React component being used with `useState`, interesting. By the way, is this whole implementation based on some resources out there, if so, can you point it to me?
thanks for that. I saw that warnings the other day and forgot to comment

can't this be more scoped? like, attached to the back layer itself instead of the window? I wonder if we will eventually have conflicting listeners on `window` if we use this same approach, on and on.
It's based on this [article](https://devrecipes.net/modal-component-with-next-js/). In his example, he doesn't have the `useState`, but without it wouldn't work.

I have to check that the actual element that I'm clicking on is within the reference. If it's not, then we close the modal. Asking `modalWrapperRef.current` is just a check to see if the reference exists at all, not necessarily if the item that we clicked is within that reference. If I remove those lines then anywhere I click inside or outside the modal will close it.
That makes sense, I'll just pass it straight in.
Great point. I removed the window listeners and instead attached the click event to the back layer.

comments.body:
Following the Page Object Model we have tests files (.spec.ts) and page files. Each page file will contain all the selectors and methods inherent to the actions an user can do in a specific page, i.e. filling out a form.

It makes easier to make updates when there are changes in the front end. 

[Best Practice - Page Object Model](https://testcafe.io/documentation/402836/guides/basic-guides/best-practices#use-of-page-objects)

pull.body:
[Registration Flow](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-97)

The goal of this change is to redirect unregistered users (i.e., those that didn't fill the three registration steps after signing up through Auth0) to the registration flow.

We still need to "attach" each form submission (on each step) to the backend. Planning to work on that next.

comments.body: Only meaningful diff between the two pages above is line 12.

`Line 25` redirects to the `registration/step-${onboardingStep}`, but this should be changed to `signup/step-${onboardingStep}`. This is reflected in current [PR 31](https://github.com/iMercatus/imercata-web/pull/31).

pull.body:
This PR:

- Creates the`<Users />` page with hardcoded dummy data
- Creates the additional options menu in a `<UserCard/>` (doesn't do anything at the moment)
- Groups components in directories where they'll solely be used (for example `<DashboardNavBar />` is moved to `components/Dashboard/`)

comments.body:
I believe this is related to the "hamburger animation" thing, right? That animation is awesome, but I do have some questions and requests related to that.

## Splitting PRs

This is for the future but, as this is not related to your current task, it will be better for you if you split this kind of thing in different PRs. Small changes like this can more easily be reviewed and merged and this will also lower the number of conflict you will have to deal with.

For example, if I leave a bunch of comments on this particular PR, then the "burger animation" won't be merged for a bunch of things that are not related to it. Then, while you fix all these other comments, someone might go there and change something on the menu (which has nothing to do with the goal of this task) and boom, someone has a conflict to fix.

Also, reviewing is cumbersome, so the less files needed to be reviewed in a PR, the better. So, in the future, please, submit these enhancements on their own PRs.

## Bundle Size

No idea if you have evaluated if this library in particular is small, but do keep in mind that we have to be careful with the libraries that we add. The more libraries we add, the bigger the app needed to be loaded by clients. I feel like this library is _not_ a problem at all, since it is supported by the original React Community on GitHub, but I wonder if you evaluated that.

Also, this is another proof that what Denis said about external dependencies doesn't make much sense. We are adding a new library here, and the very first thing they mention on their GitHub readme is: "ATTENTION! To address many issues that have come up over the years, the API in v2 and above is not backwards compatible with the original React addon (v1-stable)."

So, following what Denis said, we would be in trouble soon because they do deprecate features from time to time. Anyway, just reinforcing the point I made yesterday.

comments.body: File is called Cart and component is BaseCard. One needs to change.

I'm not used to build UIs like that, but this does look like a small mess. I mean, we have:

- `darker`: `*-gray-200`
- `dark`: `*-light-text-500`
- `light`: `*-light-text-400`
- `lighter`: `*-light-text-200`

I can almost see a pattern on the above, with `darker` being an exception. But then we have something that, to me, is completely unexpected:

- `.500`: `*-light-tertiary-500`

No idea what this means just by looking at it.

Anyway, I don't know if we want to do something here, but I do feel like there is something more... organized to do here.

> Note: I used `*-` instead of `text-` on this comment to make the similarities/differences more clear.

To be honest, I really don't understand why did you brought this to this PR. This adds more code, something you mentioned that you were trying to avoid when you were dealing with `formik` and `yup`, adds more complexity both to the code and to the PR, and it is not related to the activity you were working on.

Also, from what I'm understanding from the very first line in this document, this is a simply copy and paste from a gist. So I feel like this doesn't really match with what we were talking about the last couple of days: let's make things simple and focus on the tasks we have (or, in your words, let's be mindful about how we spend time in our activities).

By the way, I'm not saying you should remove this and I think this won't cause harm, but it did add. complexity to the PR, to the act of reviewing it, and probably you spent some time on this too. This is a comment more to understand why did you brought this here and to see if we can be aligned on how we are moving forward.

This is not how we add FontAwesome icons to the components. Check how I moved away from `<svg...` and started using a component called `FontAwesomeIcon` or similar. Also, if you don't find these exact icons in [here](https://fontawesome.com/icons/), then we have to send a message to the Design team and ask why they are not using FontAwesome icons.

Also, it is important to notice that we are using the light version of FontAwesome (light as in "thiner icons"), so avoid installing another set of icons from FontAwesome or anywhere else.
Picture is a string... so if we pass an URL, we will get an URL simply in the middle of the screen (not an image, not a link, just a URL string). Am I missing something?
I'll remove the whole hamburger/sidebar toggle transition and I'll include it on a separate PR.
I agree that there's a better way to do this. Since all the colors are basically a version of gray or blue, I'll need to name it with that in mind, but for now I've removed the `500` class.
I removed this and will include something better in a future PR.
Yeah, I copied the svgs from the mockups because the actual icons on FontAwesome are not the same. **Mockup:** **FontAwesome:**
wait, you call every other property `SomethingProps`, why change here? What if someone is importing it as a type to help on something? They will import `Props` which is unclear what it is about

Oh, you are changing everything to Props? Nope,I don't think it is a good idea. Ah, and the props are not exported? I think we will be better of calling `WhateverProps` and exporting. Someone might want to import the props to help on coding.
Will these props be used elsewhere?

pull.title: [IMERC-97] Switching to access tokens
pull.body:
[Auth0 integration adjustments](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-97)

This PR is a counterpart for [this other PR that makes the backend accept access tokens to authenticate users](https://github.com/iMercatus/imercata-backend/pull/34). Therefore, the same reasons apply, I'm opening this PR because:

1. The Next.js library to integrate with Auth0 didn't work well with this idea of sharing ID tokens with the backend. Some workaround was needed there.
2. As [Vittorio Bertocci explains here](https://auth0.com/docs/videos/learn-identity-series/calling-an-api#wistia_yw6hmdhnft?time=2126), using ID tokens to communicate with backends causes more discussions/misalignment than needed, so he encourages simply using access tokens.
3. If we ever expose the API to third-party applications, we will need to support access tokens anyway.

pull.title: [IMERC-111/112] Use Formik and yup
pull.body:
This PR: 

- converts the previous `<Input />` and `<Checkbox />` components to **Formik** components
- replaces custom validations with **yup** validations
- creates a `<SignUpForm />` which returns a customized Formik `<FormWrapper />`

_Note: the `<Input />` component has been moved to the subdirectory `src/components/SignUpForm`. It's been moved here because of the specific styling and behavior of the component (ie the transforming input label). Luckily, this input component can become more reusable with more conditional logic and less styling._

pull.title: Create Auth HOC / Refactor SignUpBottomNav
pull.body:
This PR:

- creates and uses an Auth HOC, which redirects to login page (`'/'`) if unauthorized 
- stubs out onClick event for _Continue_ button in `SignUpBottomNav`
- removes `Action` in  `SignUpBottomNav` and attaches `router.push` to Button click event (might be inelegant)

pull.title: General CSS Refactor
pull.body:
This PR: 

- replaces most external stylesheets with inline Tailwind css inside of the `src/components` directory
- uses the `clsx` module to replace the current class joining: (ie `[styles.name1, styles.2].join(' ')`). 
- updates many component props to accept a `className` to give devs more styling flexibility (based on Bruno's feedback)
- removes styling props (ie `margin` and `padding`) on some components
- updates relevant unit tests where applicable
- creates a `src/icons` directory

pull.title: [IMERC-70] Create skeleton for application
pull.body:
In fact, @zackcarlson has made most of the effort and all I needed to do was to add a NavBar to the top of the existing dashboard. So, that's what I'm doing here. Anyone checking this will eventually realize that:

1. There is no icon on the left side of the "Menu" label. That's because there is a story to configure FontAwesome.
2. There is no "Company" picker. That's because we decided to leave that to another story/task.
3. The profile button does nothing apart from being there. We haven't talked about this too, and there is no popup menu designed so far.

Hence, the PR is extremely simple.

+import React from 'react';
comments.body: What is the purpose of wrapping Next.js' `Link` into another component called `Action`? I can't see any difference in its appearance or even behavior. It looks like it is just extra work creating a test for a component that was not needed in the first place.

As mentioned above, I feel like we don't need this whole component, as we are not adding any value to it. However, I believe that the right place to use `href` while using `Link` is on the `Link` component itself: https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/link

Also, as mentioned here (https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/everyday-types.html) and here (https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/basic-types.html#about-number-string-boolean-symbol-and-object), `String`, `Boolean`, `Symbol` and `Object` should not be used. In fact, you could get yourself into trouble here because `LinkProps.href` can also be a `UrlObject`, which wouldn't convert nicely to a string.

If `linkProps.href` was in fact always a string, TypeScript wouldn't be complaining about it and you wouldn't have to cast it explicitly.
https://tailwindcss.com/docs/padding: `pt-2.5` (which means `padding: 0.625rem;`, which is the same as `10px`

I believe that just using `flex-col` from TailWind would replace `{ display: 'flex', flexDirection: 'column' }`: https://tailwindcss.com/docs/flex-direction

BTW, there is a few nice TailWind extensions for VSCode that you might want to check (if you haven't yet).
I think you can skip that props?

I am wondering... why extract the props definition to `@/typings`? What is the advantage of having this other file? I know the disadvantages (having to create another file, another line to import where I need, etc), so I wonder if we need that...

If this is for the testings that import `ButtonProps`, you can still keep them along with the components and import both with a single line where you need.

If there is a good reason, please, let me know 🙂

I think that, since we are using TailWind + modules, you don't need this. Also, if we ever need, I think letting the caller pass the whole `style` would be more flexible (just like what we have on `className`).
I'm still curious about the `@/typings` directory, as mentioned above, but if we decide to use it, should we move it there? If we won't use `@/typings`, ignore this.

In cases like this one, where this component will probably never be used again on the project (just on the onboarding/onramping/signing-up flow), prefer using a more specific name. Something like `SignUpBottomNavigation`. This makes _way_ more clear to someone reading the code in the future what the component does and where it is used.

this looks to me like a mix of concerns... is this a checkbox? is this a card? Wouldn't it make sense to have a `Card` (which will probably be used on others screens in the project) and having a `Checkbox` (also probably gonna be used in the future) as separate components?
prefer using TailWind, or something more flexible (like `style` or `className`)
I don't think we should encapsulate things inside a `label`. IIIRC, this would be a sibling of `input`: https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_label.asp
same comments as above (TailWind and using `style`/`className`, but prefer TailWind if that is enough)

If you don't have the href, then eslint will give the following error: 
```
The href attribute is required for an anchor to be keyboard accessible. 
Provide a valid, navigable address as the href value. 
If you cannot provide an href, but still need the element to resemble a link, 
use a button and change it with appropriate styles. 
Learn more: 
https://github.com/evcohen/eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y/blob/master/docs/rules/anchor-is-valid.mdeslintjsx-
```
And the `Link` component requires an anchor element.
In the previous iteration, I wasn't casting it. Instead, I hardcoded a url (``) which is perfectly fine for the Next.js `Link` because the anchor within the `Link` doesn't technically need an href.

Giving the developer the ability to add padding or margin allows them to create space when they need it, but giving them the option to completely overwrite the internal styling of the component with a style object or a classname is antithetical.

@brunokrebs I see where you're coming from but the card styles for the checkbox are completely different from the styles of a plain old card that'll be used everywhere else. Instead, I'll make a checkbox card, so that way the concerns aren't as mixed.

pull.title: [IMERC-88] Add Test Prehook
pull.body: This PR replaces the `pre-commit` hook in the `.husky` file with a `pre-push` hook instead. In the new hook, once you `git push` the script will format and lint all `.ts, .tsx` files, and then run all Testcafe test specs before pushing to git. Some temporary "fixes" were made to silence errors in the `tests/` folder, like disabling the linter in the `tests/pages/basePage.ts` due to the fact there isn't anything substantial written there quite yet.

pull.title: [IMERC-28] Configuring Auth0
pull.body:
## Task

[[IMERC-28] Configuring Auth0](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-28)

## Reasoning

This change will help the communication with the backend API by enabling the frontend app to get access to ID tokens. ID tokens contain information about the authenticated user and are the artefacts we should be using to communicate with our own backend.

If you have no idea why I'm explaining all that, the reason is because there is another artefact called access token which is usually what applications use to call APIs. The difference is that id tokens are used to call APIs inside your the boundaries of your own logical app, and access tokens are used to call third-party APIs on behalf of a user.

If you would like to learn more about this whole world, this is a very good reference:
- [Learn Identity with Vittorio Bertocci (Auth0's Principal Architect)](https://auth0.com/docs/videos/learn-identity-series)

If you are just looking for a better explanation between the differences between ID tokens and access tokens, here you go:
- [Access tokens vs ID tokens](https://auth0.com/docs/videos/learn-identity-series/calling-an-api#wistia_yw6hmdhnft?time=2007.5)

comments.body: Thanks for the docs!

pull.title: [IMERC-29] Integrate Next.js and Auth0
pull.body:
## Task

[[IMERC-29] Integrate Next.js and Auth0](https://imercatus.backlog.com/view/IMERC-29)

This PR installs and configure `@auth0/nextjs-auth0` on this project. I added a dev configuration sample to `.env.local.template`. Make sure you copy it and create a `.env.local` file in your machine (which is .gitignored) and that you add the correct values there (you can Slack me for those).

To show the usage, I added a `http://localhost:3001/secured` page that shows the integration in action. There are three possible states for this page:

1. Loading: when `@auth0/nextjs-auth0` is checking the status of the current user
2. Logged out: when the user is not logged in. This state shows a link that let them authenticate
3. Logged in: when the user is authenticated. This state shows some profile info about the user

## Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15347252/113579201-5415a780-95fa-11eb-878a-6aaf62fe9e50.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15347252/113579231-6263c380-95fa-11eb-9267-8133ed2932b1.png)

pull.title: [IMERC-33] Show Deck.GL Map
pull.body:
This PR adds a Deck.GL map to the app using react-map-gl's `<StaticMap/>` and deck.gl's `CartoSQLLayer`. There are two instances of `CartoSQLLayer` that are being invoked: **1)** to grab sample Carto nodes and **2)** to grab sample Carto paths; both of these data tables are from @brunokrebs Carto account and can be accessed using his username and apiKey in your `.env.local` file as:

```
NEXT_PUBLIC_CARTO_USERNAME="brunoskrebs"
NEXT_PUBLIC_CARTO_API_KEY="insert-api-key-here"
```

I'm not sure the best way to set up credentials to access this data, but this is the current iteration.

comments.body: I believe we will either have to handle this properly, or remove these comments completely and add a task to our backlog to handle this later.
wouldn't it make it a bit easier to read if you put a blank line between the different types?
have you written these types definitions yourself? If not, can you add a reference at the top of the file?

not sure I follow... the description of the PR mentions that:

> This PR adds a Deck.GL map to the app using Mapbox's `<StaticMap/>`

but the only reference to Mapbox that I could find was this css. Is this really being used? How does `StaticMap` relate to Mapbox?

Update, after a quick research, I realized that `react-map-gl` uses Mapbox. But now my question is, do we need Mapbox? I thought CARTO would be able to handle maps without the need of an external vendor like Mapbox.

Oh, or perhaps we are not really using Mapbox here and just using this `react-map-gl` library components to help with the map rendering process? Can you please elaborate?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,4 @@
+import * as DeckTypings from "@danmarshall/deckgl-typings";
comments.body: Can you also add a comment here to mention that this is needed because `@danmarshall/deckgl-typings` is not part of the DefinitelyTyped repository? Also, I would add a blank line between this first line (`import` statements) and the rest of the files (body) for improved readability.

@brunokrebs Yes, the `react-map-gl` is a library that helps render a base map to display our data on and in most of the Deck.gl/React examples, `react-map-gl` is the go-to map component; it incidentally uses Mapbox. In order to use CARTO, we must use the `CartoSQLLayer` from `@deck.gl/carto`, which would require us to have to build a map on CARTO's website and link that map to a database, URL, .csv, or some or kind of dataset to then actually query and show on a base map. The `StaticMap` is a way around that so that way we can get something displaying. I'm not sure if this is the best approach but this is what I've found so far.
I'll be sure to add in line breaks.
Yes, I wrote these. These are based on the [@deck.gl/carto API](https://github.com/visgl/deck.gl/tree/master/docs/api-reference/carto) definitions.

ok, so the next question is: what is the proper way to handle this? Or, why don't we create a `CartoSQLLayer`?

I'm happy merging this PR if you feel that's enough for the the sprint goal (and I actually think it might be), but we need to track that and get to the bottom of this. Perhaps you could create a task on our backlog elaborating on your findings and what we will need to do next?

So I think the proper way to handle this would be to create a sample dataset in CARTO (.csv with the sample path coordinates you gave me), link it to a map, publish it, create a `CartoSQLLayer` that points to that map, and then execute a query that loads in that info. I think that might be the way to do it in order to drop `StaticMap` and use the CARTO map.

Are you going to write down your learning on a task on our backlog? This is not the best place to refer to in the future when we get to the task when we will need this information. Also, when you do that, please, try to add as much details as needed for a person that will be reading the task one month from now or similar. There you can also link to this PR.

comments.body:
actually, this file was created by Next.js itself. [From their docs](https://nextjs.org/docs/basic-features/typescript):

> A file named next-env.d.ts will be created in the root of your project. This file ensures Next.js types are picked up by the TypeScript compiler. You cannot remove it, however, you can edit it (but you don't need to).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,25 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+
+set -x
+
+export REQUIRED_NODE_VERSION=14.16
+
+# Check for node
+if ! [ -x "$(command -v node)" ]; then
+    echo 'Error: node is not installed.' >&2
+    exit 1
+fi
+
+# Detect required Node major/minor version for Active LTS.
+node_version="$(node -v | cut -c2-)"
+node_major_minor_version=${node_version%.*}
+
+if [ $node_major_minor_version == $REQUIRED_NODE_VERSION ]; then
+    echo "Success: Node v${REQUIRED_NODE_VERSION}.* found."
+else
+    echo "Error: node v${REQUIRED_NODE_VERSION}.* not found, please install."
+    exit 1
+fi
+
+# Install app and development dependencies
+npm install
